to come near, approach: c. dat. pers., Mar.10.35.†
to break against, dash against; (a) trans. (παιδία πέτραις, FlJ, Ant., ix, 4, 6); (b) intrans., c. dat.: Luk.6.48-49 (cf. προσπίπτω).†

1. c. acc pers., to place at, to attach to.; 2. to give a command, enjoin, appoint: Luk.5.14; c. dat. pers., Mat.1.24; c. acc rei, Mat.8.4, Mar.1.44; c. acc et inf., Act.10.48; pass., Act.10.33; Act.17.26.†
a patroness, protectress: Rom.16.2.†

1. to put to.; 2. to add, join to, give in addition: c. acc seq. ἐπί, Mat.6.27, Luk.3.20; Luk.12.25; ἐπὶ τὸ αὐτό, Act.2.47; c. acc et dat., Luk.17.5, Heb.12.19 (v. MM, xxi); pass., absol., Act.2.41, Gal.3.19; c. dat., Mat.6.33, Mar.4.24, Luk.12.31, Act.5.14; Act.11.24; προσιτέθη πρὸς τ. πατέρας (cf. Gen.26.8, Jdg.2.10, al.), Act.13.36; c. inf., of repeating or continuing the action signified by the following verb, as in Heb. idiom (Gen.4.2; Gen.8.12, al.; cf. WM, § 54, 5; Lft. on Clem., 1Co., xii; but v. also M, Pr., 67, 233; Deiss., BS, 67.1; MM, xxi), Luk.20.11, Act.12.3; similarly ptcp., προσ-θείς, c. indic. (Gen.38.5, al.), Luk.19.11.†
to run to: Mar.9.15; Mar.10.17, Act.8.30.†

Hellenistic for ὄψον ὀψάριον),; a relish or dainty (esp, cooked fish), to be eaten with bread: Joh.21.5 (have ye taken any fish, Field, Notes, 109; Abbott, Essays, 105; cf. M, Pr., 170n; MM, Exp., xxi).†
1. originally, freshly slain.; 2. Generally (from Æsch. on), new, fresh, recent: ὁδός, Heb.10.20 (v. MM, Exp., xxi; Rutherford, NPhr., 471 f.).†
recently: Act.18.2 (v. MM, Exp., xxi).†

1. to bring to, lead to: c. acc et dat. pers., Mat.4.24; Mat.8.16; Mat.9.2; Mat.9.32; Mat.14.35; Mat.17.16, Mar.2.4 (WH, R, txt.; sc. αὐτόν) Mar.10.13, Luk.18.15; Luk.23.14; pass., Mat.12.22 (act., WH, txt.) Mat.18.24 (προσήχθη, WH) Mat.19.13; c. acc rei, Mat.25.20; id. c. dat. pers., Mat.22.19, Luk.23.36; τ. στόματι, Joh.19.29; metaph., c. dat pers., to deal with, Heb.12.7 (cl.).; 2. to offer: Mat.2.11, Act.8.18; esp. (as freq. in LXX; cf. FlJ, Ant., iii, 9, 3) sacrifices, gifts and prayers to God: absol., seq. περί (ὑπέρ), Mar.1.44, Luk.5.14, Heb.5.1; Heb.5.3; Heb.9.7; Heb.10.12; pass., Act.21.26; c. acc rei (δῶρον, θυσίαν, λυτρείαν, προσφοράν), Mat.5.23-24 (aoristic pres.; M, Pr., 247) Mat.8.4, Joh.16.2, Act.7.42; Act.21.26, Heb.5.1; Heb.8.3-4; Heb.9.7; Heb.9.9; Heb.10.1-2; Heb.10.8; Heb.10.11-12; δεήσεις τε κ. ἱκετηρίας, Heb.5.7; c. acc pers., Heb.11.17 (conative impf.; M, Pr., 129); of Christ, Heb.7.27 (ἀνενέγκας, WH, txt.) Heb.9.14; Heb.9.25; Heb.9.28.†
(a) of persons, in both act, and pass. sense (LXX, ll. c.); (b) of things, pleas­ing, agreeable (EV, lovely): Php.4.8.†

1. a bringing to, offering (Plat., al.).; 2. (Less freq. in cl.), a present, an offering; in NT, of sacrificial offerings: Act.21.26; Act.24.17, Eph.5.2, Heb.10.5; Heb.10.8; Heb.10.14; περί ἀμαρτίας, Heb.10.18; c. gen. obj., Rom.15.16, Heb.10.10.†

1. to address, call to; in cl., c. acc pers., c. dupl. acc (cf. 2Mac, l.c.); absol. (Hom., Od., v, 159, al.): Act.21.40 In late writers, c. dat. pers.: Mat.11.16, Luk.7.32; Luk.13.12; Luk.23.20, Act.22.2.; 2. to call by name, summon: c. acc (as in cl.), Luk.6.13.†
a pouring or sprinkling upon: Heb.11.28.†
in poët. and late writers,; to touch: c. dat., Luk.11.46.†
to have respect of persons: Jas.2.9.†
a respecter of persons: Act.10.34
respect of persons: Rom.2.11, Eph.6.9, Col.3.25, Jas.2.1 (v. Mayor, in l).†

1. prop., of persons (so always in cl.); (a) the face, countenance: Mat.6.16-17, Mar.14.65, Luk.9.29, 2Co.3.7, Rev.4.7, al.; τὸ Papyri τῆς γενέτεως (EV, natural face), Jas.1.23; πίπτειν ἐπὶ (τὰ) Papyri, Mat.17.6, Luk.5.12, Rev.7.11, al.; ἀγνοούμενος τῷ Papyri, Gal.1.22; Papyri, οὐ καρδίᾳ, 1Th.2.17; κατὰ πρόσωπον (in front, facing: Thuc., Xen., al.), when present, face to face, Act.25.16, 2Co.10.1; 2Co.10.7, Gal.2.11; id. c. gen., as compound prep., in the presence of (not cl.; v. Bl., § 40, 9; M, Pr., 99 f.; Thackeray, Gr., 43 f.), Luk.2.31, Act.3.13; similarly ἀπὸ Papyri (Heb. (H6440 מִלִּפְּנֵי); v. Dalman, Words, 29), from the presence of, Act.3.19; Act.5.41; Act.7.45, 2Th.1.9, Rev.12.14; Rev.20.11; πρὸ Papyri (Heb. (H6440 לִפְנֵי), before, Mat.11.10, Mar.1.2, Luk.7.27 (LXX), al.; in other phrases resembling Heb. idiom (Thackeray, Gr., 42), βλέπειν (ὁρᾶν, θεωρεῖν, ἰδεῖν) τὸ Papyri, to see one's face, i.e. see him in person, Mat.18.10, Act.20.25; Act.20.38, 1Th.3.10, Rev.22.4; ἐμφανισθῆναι τῷ Papyri τοῦ θεοῦ, Heb.9.24; ἐν Papyri Χριστοῦ, 2Co.2.10; 2Co.4.6; μετὰ τοῦ Papyri σου with thy presence, Act.2.28 (LXX); εἰς Papyri τῶν ἐκκλησιῶν, 2Co.8.24; στηρίζειν τὸ Papyri (Heb. H6440 H7760: Jer.21.10, al.; v. Dalman, Words, 30), c. inf., to set one's face towards, Luk.9.51; similarly, τὸ Papyri αὐτοῦ ἦν πορευόμενον (op. cit., 31), Luk.9.53; τὸ Papyri τοῦ κυρίου ἐπί, 1Pe.3.12 (LXX); (b) form, person: καυχᾶσθαι. ἐν Papyri καὶ μὴ ἐν καρδίᾳ, 2Co.5.12 (cf. 1Sa.16.7); metaph., as in Heb. idiom, of judgment according to appearance, external condition or circumstances (H6440 H5387; v. Dalman, Words, 30; Thackeray, Gr., 43 f.): λαμβάνειν Papyri, Luk.20.21, Gal.2.6; βλέπειν εἰς Papyri, Mat.22.16, Mar.12.14; θαυμάζειν πρόσωπα, Jud.1.16.; 2. Of things (cf. Dalman, l.c.); (a) face, appearance (Psa.104.30): Mat.16.3 (WH, R, mg., om.), Luk.12.56, Jas.1.11; (b) surface (Gen.2.6): Luk.21.35, Act.17.26.
1. to place in front.; 2. to arrange beforehand: Act.17.26, Rec. (for προστ., Edd.).†
to stretch out, stretch forth: of preparations for scourging (v. Field, Notes, 136 f.), Act.22.25.†

A. Comparative,; πρότερος, -α, -ον,; before, of time, place, rank, etc.; in NT always of Time, before, former: Eph.4.22. Adverbially, πρότερον, before, aforetime, formerly: Joh.7.50, 2Co.1.15, Heb.4.6; opp. to ἔπειτα, Heb.7.27; τὸ Papyri, Joh.6.62; Joh.9.8, Gal.4.13, 1Ti.1.13; αἱ Papyri ἡμέραι, Heb.10.32; αί Papyri αἱ Papyri ἐπιθυμίαι, 1Pe.1.14.†; B. Superlative.,; πρῶτος, -η, -ον,; first,; 1. of Time or Place; (a) absol., as subst., ὁ Papyri, Luk.14.18, Joh.19.32, 1Co.14.30; ὁ Papyri καὶ ὁ ἔσχατος, Rev.1.17; Rev.2.8; Rev.22.13; neut., τὸ Papyri, opp. to τ. δεύτερον, Heb.10.9; τὰ Papyri, opp. to τ. ἔσχατα, Mat.12.45, Luk.11.26, 2Pe.2.20; anarth., Mat.10.2; pl., Mat.19.30, Mar.10.31, Luk.13.30; ἐν πρώτοις (EV, first of all ), 1Co.15.3; (b) as adj.: πρώτῃ (sc. ἡμέρᾳ) σαββάτου, Mar.16.9; φυλακή, ορρ. to δευτέρα, Act.12.10; equiv. to adv. in English, Joh.8.7; Joh.20.4; Joh.20.8, Act.27.43, Rom.10.19, 1Ti.1.16, 1Jn.4.19; = πρότερος (v. infr.; cf. M, Pr.. 79; Bl., § 11, 5; Thackeray, Go., 183 f.): c. gen., Papyri μου ἦν (my chief: Abbott, Jg., 509 ff.; but cf. M, Pr., 245), Joh.1.15; Joh.1.30; c. art., Mar.14.12, Act.1.1, al.; seq. ὁ δεύτερος, etc., Mat.22.25, Mar.12.20, al.; 2. Of Rank or Dignity, chief, principal: Mat.20.27; Mat.22.38, Mar.9.35, Eph.6.2, al.; c. gen., Mar.12.28-29, al.; πόλις (Field, Notes, 124), Act.16.12; c. art., Luk.15.22; Luk.19.47, Act.13.50, al.; 3. Neut., πρῶτον, as adv., first, at the first; (a) of Time: Mat.8.21, Mar.4.28, al.; τὸ Papyri, Joh.10.40, al.; (b) of Order: Rom.3.2, 1Co.11.18, al.

1. to set before, set forth publicly; so also in mid.: c. acc pers., Rom.3.25 (for a suggested alt, rend., v. MM, xxii).; 2. Mid., to set before oneself, propose, purpose: c. inf., Rom.1.13; c. acc rei, Eph.1.9.†
to urge forwards, exhort, persuade. Mid., in same sense (as also in cl.): Act.18.27.†
1. to run forward.; 2. to run on, run in advance: Joh.20.4; seq. εἰς τὸ ἔμπροσθεν, Luk.19.4.†
1. to be beforehand in.; 2. to be before or previously: c. ptcp., Luk.23.12, Act.8.9.†
a pretence, pretext: Mat.23.1 (WM, R, txt., om.), Mar.12.40, Luk.20.47 Joh.15.22, Act.27.30, Php.1.18, 1Th.2.5.†
to bring forth: c. acc rei, seq. ἐκ, Luk.6.45.†

the gift (and its exercise) of interpreting the Divine will and purpose, prophecy, prophesying: of OT prophecy, Mat.13.14, 2Pe.1.20-21; of NT prophecy, Rom.12.6, 1Co.12.10; 1Co.13.2; 1Co.14.6; 1Co.14.22, 1Ti.4.14, Rev.11.6; Rev.22.19; pl., 1Co.13.8, 1Th.5.20, 1Ti.1.18; οἱ λόγοι τῆς Papyri, Rev.1.3; Rev.22.7; Rev.22.10; Rev.22.18; τ. πνεῦμα τῆς Papyri, Rev.19.10 (Luc., FlJ, LXX, Papyri; v. Deiss., BS, 235 f.; MM, xxii).†

to be a προφήτης (q.v.), to prophesy: in the primary sense of telling forth the Divine counsels, Mat.7.22; Mat.26.68, Mar.14.65, Luk.1.67; Luk.22.64, Act.19.6, 1Co.11.4-5; 1Co.13.9; 1Co.14.1; 1Co.14.3-5; 1Co.14.24; 1Co.14.31; 1Co.14.39, Heb.11.3; with the idea of foretelling future events (an idea merely incidental, not essential; v. Lft., Notes, 83 f.), Mat.11.13, Act.2.17-18 (LXX) Act.21.9; seq. περί, Mat.15.7, Mar.7.6, 1Pe.1.10; ἐπί, c. dat., Rev.10.11; λέγων, Jud.1.14; ὅτι, Joh.11.51.†; SYN.: μαντεύομαι G3132, q.v.

one who acts as an interpreter or forth-teller of the Divine will (v. Lft., Notes, 83 I.; Tr., Syn., § vi), a prophet; 1. in cl. (Æsch., Hdt., Plat., a1.), of the interpreters of oracles.; 2. In NT,; (a) of the OT prophets: Mat.5.12, Mar.6.15, Luk.4.27, Joh.8.52, Rom.11.3, al.; (b) of prophets in general: Mat.10.41; Mat.13.57; Mat.21.46, Mar.6.4, Luk.13.33, al.; (c) of John the Baptist: Mat.21.26, Mar.6.15, Luk.1.76; (d) of Christ: Mat.21.11, Joh.6.14, Act.3.22-23; Act.7.37 (LXX); (e) of Christian prophets in the apostolic age: Act.15.32, 1Co.12.28, Eph.2.20, al.; (f) by meton., of the writings of prophets: Luk.24.27 Act.8.28, al.; (g) of a poet: Tit.1.12 (on the use of the term in Papyri and Inscr., v. Deiss., BS, 235 f.; MM, xxii).
of prophecy, prophetic: Rom.16.26, 2Pe.1.19.†
fem, of προφήτης,; a prophetess: Luk.2.36, Rev.2.20.†
c. ptcp. (as in cl., but more freq. the simple φθάνω, q.v.),; to anticipate: Mat.17.25.†

1. to put into the hand, deliver up: pass., Act.3.20.; 2. More freq. as depon., -ομαι, to take into one's hand; hence, metaph., to propose, determine, choose: c. inf., Act.22.14; c. acc pers., Act.26.16.†
to choose or appoint beforehand: Act.10.41 (Plat., al.).†
Prochorus: Act.6.5.
prop. fem. of adj. πρύμνο, -η, -ον, (sc. ναῦς), the hindmost part of a ship, the stern: Mar.4.38, Act.27.29; opp. to πρῷρα, Act.27.41.†
adv.
πρώιος; at early morn, early; as subst., ἡ Papyri (sc. ὥρα, cf. ἡ ὥ. ἡ Papyri, 3Ma.5.24), early morning: Mat.27.1, Joh.21.4.†
πρόϊμος; = the more common πρώιος (q.v.),; early: of rain (as most freq. in LXX), Jas.5.7.†
= cl. πρώιος,; at early morn, early: ἀστήρ, Rev.2.28; Rev.22.16.†
to be first, pre-eminent, have the first place: Col.1.18.†
the chief seat: Mat.23.6, Mar.12.39 (v. Swete, in l), Luk.11.43; Luk.20.46.†
the chief place at table (v. Swete, Mk., l.c.): Mat.23.6, Mar.12.39, Luk.14.7-8; Luk.20.46.†
adv.,; first: Act.11.26.†
prop., of soldiers, one who stands first, one in the front rank (Thuc., Xen.); hence, metaph., a leader: Act.24.5.†
the rights of the first-born, birthright (= cl. ἡ πρεσβεία): Heb.12.16.†

first-born: Luk.2.7; pl., Heb.11.28. Metaph., of the priority of Christ (originally perh. a Messianic title, cf. Psa.89.28, Heb.1.6; v. ICC on Col.1.15): Heb.1.6; Papyri πάσης κτίσεως, Col.1.15; ἐν πολλοῖς ἀδελφοῖς, Rom.8.29; Papyri (ἐκ) τ. νεκρῶν, Col.1.18, Rev.1.5; pl., of the elect, ἐκκλησία πρωτοτόκων, Heb.12.23.†
1. trans., to cause to stumble (1Sa.4.3, cf. Deiss., BS, 681).; 2. Intrans., to stumble. Metaph., in moral sense, Rom.11.11, Jas.2.10; Jas.3.2, 2Pe.1.10.†
the heel: fig., ἐπαίρειν τὴν Papyri ἐπί, Joh.13.18 (LXX).†
1. a little wing.; 2. Anything like a wing, as a turret, battlement: τ. ἱεροῦ, Mat.4.5, Luk.4.9.†
a wing: of birds, Mat.23.37, Luk.13.34, Rev.12.14; of creatures seen in a vision, Rev.4.8; Rev.9.9.†
winged; as subst., Papyri, birds: 1Co.15.39.†
to terrify. Pass., to be terrified: Luk.21.9; Luk.24.37 (WH, mg., θροηθέντες).†
a fluttering, excitement, caused by any emotion, but esp. by fear, hence, terror: φοβεῖσθαι πτόησιν, to be afraid with (cogn. acc) or of any terror (v. ICC, in l): 1Pe.3.6.†
Ptolemais, a maritime city of Phœnicea: Act.21.7.†
a winnowing shovel or fan: Mat.3.12, Luk.3.17.†
depon.,; to be startled, frightened: Php.1.28. (The active πτύρω is also found in some late writers.) †
spittle: Joh.9.6 (Hipp., Polyb., al.).†
to fold; of a scroll, to roll up: βιβλίον, Luk.4.20 (cf. ἀνα-πτύσσω).†
to spit: Mar.7.33; Mar.8.23, Joh.9.6 (cf. ἐκ-, ἐμ-πτύω).†

1. a fall, metaph., a misfortune, calamity (Trag., Plat., Polyb., al.; LXX).; 2. That which has fallen; (a) of buildings, a ruin (Polyb.); (b) of living creatures, in cl. (poët. only) usually c. gen., νεκρῶν, etc., but also absol., as in late writers and NT, a fallen body, a carcase, corpse: Mat.14.12; Mat.24.28, Mar.15.45; Papyri αὐτοῦ, Mar.6.29; αὐτῶν, Rev.11.8-9 (cf. Rutherford, NPhr., 472 f.).†
a falling, fall (Plat., Plut., al.): Mat.7.27; metaph., Luk.2.34.†
beggary, destitution: 2Co.8.2; 2Co.8.9, Rev.2.9.†
1. to be a beggar, to beg (so chiefly in cl.).; 2. to be poor as a beggar, to be destitute, poor: opp. to πλούσιος ὤν, 2Co.8.9.†

of one who crouches and cowers, hence,; 1. as subst., a beggar: Luk.14.13; Luk.14.21; Luk.16.20; Luk.16.22.; 2. As adj.,; (a) prop., beggarly: metaph., στοιχεῖα, Gal.4.9 (v. Lft., in l); (b) in broader sense (opp. to πλούσιος), poor: Mat.11.5; Mat.19.21; Mat.26.9; Mat.26.11, Mar.10.21; Mar.12.42-43; Mar.14.5; Mar.14.7, Luk.4.18; Luk.7.22; Luk.18.22; Luk.19.8; Luk.21.3, Joh.12.5-6; Joh.12.8; Joh.13.29, Rom.15.26, 2Co.6.10, Gal.2.10, Jas.2.2-3; Jas.2.6, Rev.13.16; Papyri τ. κόσμῳ, Jas.2.5; metaph., Luk.6.20, Rev.3.17; Papyri τ. πνεύματι, Mat.5.3.†; SYN.: πένης G3993, q.v.

the fist: πυγμῇ νίψασθαι τ. χῖρας (Τ, πυκνά; Vg., Goth., Copt., crebro), to wash the hands with the fist (diligently, R, txt.; up to the elbow, R, mg.; the exact meaning is doubtful; v. Swete, in l): Mar.7.3.†

1. in cl., Python, a serpent slain by Apollo, who is hence surnamed the Pythian.; 2. In Plut. (ii, 414 E), a name given to ventriloquist soothsayers (ἐγγαστρίμυθοι; cf. Lev.19.31; Lev.20.6; Lev.20.27, 1Sa.28.7), and perhaps in this sense πνεῦμα πύθωνα, a python-spirit: Act.16.16.†

1. close, compact, solid.; 2. frequent: 1Ti.5.23. Neut. pl., πυκνά, as adv., much, often: Mar.7.3 Τ (see πυγμή), Luk.5.33. Comparat., πυκνότερον, very often or so much the oftener (v.Bl., § 44, 3,): Act.24.26.†
to box: 1Co.9.26.†
a gate: Luk.7.12, Act.9.24; Act.12.10; Act.16.13, Heb.13.12; ἡ Ὡραία Π. τ. ἱεροῦ, Act.3.10. Metaph., Mat.7.13-14; πύλαι ᾅδου (Wis.16.13, 3Ma.5.51, and cf. κλαῖς ᾅδου Rev.1.18): Mat.16.18.†

1. the porch or vestibule of a house or palace: Mat.26.71, Luk.16.20, Act.10.17; Act.12.13-14; 2. The gate-way or gate-tower of a walled town: Act.14.13, Rev.21.12-13; Rev.21.15; Rev.21.21; Rev.21.25; Rev.22.14.†

1. to inquire: c. acc rei, Joh.4.42, Act.23.20; seq. quæst. indir., Mat.2.4, Luk.15.25; Luk.18.36, Act.10.18; Act.21.33; quæst. dir., Act.4.7; Act.10.20; Act.23.10; seq. παρά, c. gen. pers., Mat.2.4, Joh.4.52.; 2. to learn by inquiry: seq. ὅτι, Act.23.34.†

gen., πυρός, τό,; fire: Mar.9.22, Luk.3.9, Joh.15.6, Act.2.10, 1Co.3.13, Jas.3.5, Rev.8.5, al; Papyri καὶ θεῖον, Luk.17.29; κατακαίειν (ἐν) Papyri, Mat.13.40, Rev.17.16; Rev.18.8; καίεσθαι πυρί, Heb.12.18, Rev.8.8; Rev.21.8; φλὸξ πυρός, Act.7.30, 2Th.1.8, Heb.1.7, Rev.1.14; Rev.2.18; Rev.19.12; λαμπάδες πυρός, Rev.4.5; στῦλοι πυρός, Rev.10.1; ἄνθρακες πυρός,, Rom.12.20 (LXX); γλῶσσαι ὡσεὶ πυρός, Act.2.3; δοκιμάζειν (πυροῦσθαι) διὰ πυρός, 1Pe.1.7, Rev.3.18; ὡς διὰ. Papyri (Lft., Notes, 193), 1Co.3.15. Of the fire of hell (cf. Dalman, Words,161): Mar.9.48 (LXX); τὸ Papyri τὸ αἰώνιον, Mat.18.8; Mat.25.41 (cf. 4Ma.12.12); ἄσβεστον, Mar.9.43; πυρὸς αἰωνίου δίκην ὑπέχειν, Jud.1.7; γέεννα τοῦ π,, Mat.5.22; Mat.18.9; κάμινος τοῦ π,, Mat.13.42; Mat.13.50; ἡ λίμνη τοῦ π,, Rev.19.20; Rev.20.10; Rev.20.14-15; πυρὶ τηρεῖσθαι, 2Pe.3.7; βασανισθῆναι ἐν Papyri, Rev.14.10. Metaph.: βαπτίζειν πυρί, Luk.3.16; of the tongue, Jas.3.5; of strife and discord, Luk.12.49; ἐκ Papyri ἁρπάζειν, Jud.1.23; πυρὶ αλίζεσθαι, Mar.9.49; ζῆλος πυρός, Heb.10.27; of God, π, καταναλίσκον, Heb.12.29 (LXX).
a fire: Act.28.2-3.†
a tower: Luk.13.4; of a watch-tower in a vineyard (Isa.5.2): Mat.21.33, Mar.12.1, and prob., Luk.14.28.†
to be ill of a fever: Mat.8.14, Mar.1.3.†
a fever: Mat.8.15, Mar.1.31, Luk.4.39, Joh.4.52, Act.28.8; Papyri μέγας, a high fever: Luk.4.38 (on the technical phrase here, v. MM, xxii).†
fiery: Rev.9.17.†

to set on fire, burn up. In NT always pass.,; 1. to be set on fire, to burn: Eph.6.16, 2Pe.3.12; ptcp., glowing, Rev.1.15. Metaph., of grief or indignation, 2Co.11.29; of lust, 1Co.7.9.; 2. Of metals (cf. Job.22.25, Psa.12.7, Zec.13.9), to be refined or purified by fire: Rev.3.18 (and so in RV, Rev.1.15, but v. supr.).†
to be fiery red: Mat.16.2-3.†
fiery red: Rev.6.4; Rev.12.3.†; Πύρρος, -ου, ὁ,; Pyrrhus: Act.20.4.†
1. a burning: Rev.18.9; Rev.18.18.; 2. a refining or trial by fire: metaph., 1Pe.4.12.†
enclit. part.,; yet, see μή-πω, μηδέ-πω, οὔ-πω, οὐδέ-πω, πώ-ποτε.

1. to exchange or barter.; 2. to sell: Luk.17.28, Rev.13.17; οἱ πωλοῦντες, Mat.21.12; Mat.25.9, Mar.11.15, Luk.19.45; c. acc rei, Mat.13.44; Mat.19.21; Mat.21.12, Mar.10.21; Mar.11.15, Luk.12.33; Luk.18.22; Luk.22.36, Joh.2.14; Joh.2.16 Act.5.1 (sc. αὐτά, αὐτόν), Act.4.34; Act.4.37. Pass., 1Co.10.25; c. gen. pretii, Mat.10.29, Luk.12.6.†

a foal, colt, prop., of a horse, then the young of other animals; in NT of the colt of an ass: Mat.21.2; Mat.21.5 (LXX), Mat.21.7, Mar.11.2; Mar.11.4-5; Mar.11.7, Luk.19.30; Luk.19.33; Luk.19.35, Joh.12.15 (LXX).†
to petrify, harden, form a callus. Metaph., Papyri τ. καρδίαν, Joh.12.40. Pass., Rom.11.7; τ. νοήματα, 2Co.3.14; ἡ καρδία, Mar.6.52; Mar.8.17 †
a covering with a callus, a hardening: metaph., Mar.3.6, Rom.11.2, Eph.4.18.†
enclit. part.,; at all; see εἴπως, μήπως.

interrog. adv., correl. of ὅπως,; 1. prop., in direct questions, how ?: c. indic., Mat.12.29, Mar.3.23, Luk.11.18, Joh.3.4, al.; Καὶ Papyri, Mar.4.13, Luk.20.44; Papyri οὖν, Mat.12.26; Papyri οὐ, Mat.16.11, Luk.12.56; in deliberative questions (cf. Bl., § 64, 6), c. subjc., Mat.23.33; Mat.26.54; Papyri οὖν, Rom.10.14; Papyri δέ Rom.10.14-15; seq. ἄν, c. optat., Act.8.31.; 2. As sometimes in cl. but more freq. and increasingly so in late writers (v. WM, § 57, 2; B1., § 70, 2; Thumb, MGr., 192; Jannaris, Gr., App., vi, 13 f.), = ὅπως, ὥς; (a) in indirect discourse: c. indic., Mat.6.28, Mar.12.41, Luk.8.36, Joh.9.15, Act.9.27, al.; c. subjc., Mar.11.18, Luk.12.11; (b) in exclamations: Mat.21.20, Mar.10.23-24, Luk.12.20; Luk.18.24, Joh.11.36.
Rahab (LXX, Jos.2.1, al.): Heb.11.31, Jas.2.25.†

a title of respectful address to Jewish teachers, Rabbi: Mat.23.7-8; of John, Joh.3.26; of Christ, Mat.26.25; Mat.26.49, Mar.9.5; Mar.11.21; Mar.14.45, Joh.1.30; Joh.1.50; Joh.3.2; Joh.4.31; Joh.6.25; Joh.9.2; Joh.11.8; κύριε ῥ Mar.10.51 (WH, mg., see ῥαββουνεί).†
Rabboni: Mar.10.51 (WH, mg., κύριε ῥαββεί), Joh.20.16.†
to beat with a rod: Act.16.22, 2Co.11.25.†

a staff, rod: Heb.9.4, Rev.11.1; in particular,; (a) a staff, such as is used on a journey: Mat.10.10, Mar.6.8, Luk.9.3, Heb.11.21 (LXX); (b) a ruler's staff, a sceptre: Heb.1.8 (LXX) Rev.2.27; Rev.12.5; Rev.19.15; (c) a rod for chastisement (cf. ῥαβδίζω): ἐν ῥ. (see ἐν): 1Co.4.21.†
one who carries a rod or staff of office; (a) an umpire or judge (Plat.); (b) in late writers, a Roman lictor: Act.16.38.†
indecl.; Reu: Luk.3.35.†
1. a reckless act.; 2. crime, villany: Act.18.14.†
1. ease in doing, facility (Xen.).; 2. easiness, laziness (Xen.).; 3. recklessness, wickedness (of lewdness, Xen.; fraud, Plut.; in Papyri, of theft, MM, xxii): Act.13.10.†
ῥαχά, see ῥακά.
1. a ragged garment (Hom.).; 2. a rag, remnant, piece of cloth: Mat.9.16, Mar.2.21.†
indecl.; Ramah: Mat.2.18 (LXX).†

= cl., ῥαίνω,; to sprinkle, besprinkle: c. acc, Heb.9.13; Heb.9.19; id. et dat., Heb.9.21; pass., Rev.19.13, WH; of cleansing by sprinkling, Heb.10.22 (v. M, Gr., ii, 100); mid., Mar.7.4 (WH, txt., R, mg.).†; περι-ραίνω; to sprinkle around: Rev.19.13 T (ῤεραντισμένον, WH; ῤε-, R, txt.; βεβαμμένον, Rec., R, mg.).†
1. prop., to strike with a rod.; 2. In late writers, to strike (the face) with the palm of the hand: Mat.26.67; c. acc pers., seq. εἰς τ. σιαγόνα, Mat.5.39 (cf. Field, Notes, 40, 105).†
a needle: Mat.19.24, Mar.10.25 (cf. βελόνη).†
indecl.; Rachel: Mat.2.18 (LXX).†
Rebecca: Rom.9.10.†
a chariot: Rev.18.13.†
Ῥομφά (-άν, T; Ῥεφάν, LTr.; Ῥεμφάν, Rec.; v. WH, App., 92),; Rompha, Rephan (RV), one of the names of Seb, the Egyptian Saturn: Act.7.43 (LXX).†
to flow: Joh.7.38 (cf. παραρρέω).†
Rhegium, a town in Sicily: Act.28.13.†
1. cl. (and so in LXX), a fracture; then by meton., that which is torn.; 2. In NT, ruin: Luk.6.49.†

and (Mar.9.18) ῥήσσω,; 1. to rend, break asunder: Mat.7.6, Mar.2.22, Luk.5.37; pass., Mat.9.17.; 2. Of the voice, c. acc, φωνήν, etc. (Hdt., al.), to break forth into speech: absol., Gal.4.27 (LXX).; 3. = ῥήσσω (Dem., al.), to throw or dash down: Mar.9.18, Luk.9.42; SYN.: θραύω G2352, κατάγνυμι G2608.; ῥήσσω, see ῥήγνυμι.

1. prop., of that which is said or spoken,; (a) a word: Mat.27.14, 2Co.12.4; pl., τὰ ῥ., of speech, discourse, Luk.7.1, Joh.8.20, Act.2.14, Rom.10.18, 2Pe.3.2, al.; (b) opp. to ὄνομα (a single word), a saying, statement, word of prophecy, instruction or command (in cl., phrase): Mat.26.75, Mar.9.32, Luk.1.38; Luk.2.50, Act.11.16, Rom.10.8, Heb.11.3; ῥ. θεοῦ (κυρίου), Luk.3.2, Act.11.16, Eph.6.17, Heb.6.5; Heb.11.3, 1Pe.1.25 (LXX); τὰ ῥ. τ. θεοῦ, Joh.3.34; Joh.8.47; ῥ. ἀργόν, Mat.12.36;ῥ. ἄρρητα, 2Co.12.4.; 2. Like Heb. H1697 (but perh. also a Gk. colloquialism, v. Kennedy, Sources, 124; Thackeray, Gr., 41), of that which is the subject of speech, a thing, matter (Gen.15.1, Deu.17.8, al.): Luk.1.37; Luk.2.15, Act.10.37; pl., Luk.1.65; Luk.2.19; Luk.2.51, Act.5.32; Act.13.42.
indecl.,; Rhesa: Luk.3.27.†
a public speaker, an orator: Act.24.1.†
adv.; in stated terms, expressly: 1Ti.4.1.†

a root: Mat.3.10, Luk.3.9; ἐκ ῥιζῶν, Mar.11.20; ῥ. ἔχειν, Mat.13.6, Mar.4.6; id. seq. ἐν ἑαυτῷ, fig., Mat.13.21, Mar.4.17, Luk.8.13. Metaph. (as in various senses in cl.), of cause, origin, source, etc.; (a) of things, ῥ. πάντων τ. κακῶν (Eur.), 1Ti.6.10; (b) of persons: of ancestors, Rom.11.16-18; ῥ. πικρίας, Heb.12.15. Of that which springs from a root, a shoot; metaph., of offspring, Rom.15.12 (LXX) Rev.5.5; Rev.22.16.†
to cause to take root. Metaph., to plant, fix firmly, establish: pass. (EV, rooted), ἐν ἀγάπῃ, Eph.3.18(17); ἐν Χριστῷ, Col.2.7 (cf. ἐκ ριζόω).†

poët. in cl., any rapid movement such as the throw or flight of a javelin, the rush of wind or flame, the flapping of wings, the twinkling of lights; ῥ. ὀφθαλμοῦ, the twinkling of an eye: 1Co.15.52 (L, mg., ῥοπή, q.v.).†; ῥοπή, -ῆς, ἡ; inclination downwards, as the turn of the scale: L, mg., for ῥιπή, q.v., 1Co.15.52 (v. Tdf., in l).†

primarily, to fan a fire, hence generally, to make a breeze (Plut., al.). In pass. (cf. Philo, de inter. round., 24), to be tossed or blown by the wind: of waves, ἀνεμιζομένῳ καὶ ῥιπιζομένῳ, blown and raised with the wind (Hort, in l), Jas.1.6.†

and (Act.22.23) ῥιπτέω (strengthened form; v. Veitch, s.v. ῥίπτω, fin.),; 1. to throw, cast, hurl: c. acc rei, Mat.27.5, Act.27.19; Act.27.29; c. acc pers., Mat.15.30, Luk.4.35; pass., Luk.17.2; ptcp., ἐριμμένοι, cast down, prostrate (Polyb., al.): Mat.9.36; of garments, to throw off (for flight, Eur., Xen., al.; ὅπλα, 1Ma.5.43; so EV in Act.22.23, but v. infr.).; 2. = ῥιπτάζω, to shake, toss, throw about: τ. ἱμάτια, Act.22.23 (EGT, Page, Rackham, in l; Field, Notes, 136; but v. supr.).†
indecl.; Rehoboam: Mat.1.7.†
Rhoda: Act.12.13.†
the island of Rhodes: Act.21.1.†
adv.; with rushing sound (as of roaring flames): 2Pe.3.10.†

a large broad sword, used by the Thracians (v. DB, iv, 634); then generally (in LXX used interchangeably with μάχαιρα, q.v.), a sword: Rev.1.16; Rev.2.12; Rev.2.16; Rev.6.8; Rev.19.15; Rev.19.21; metaph., Luk.2.35.†
indecl.,; Reuben: Rev.7.5.†
indecl.; Ruth: Mat.15.1-39.†
Rufus: Mar.15.21, Rom.16.13.†

1. in cl., the force, rush, swing, of a moving body; esp. of a charge of soldiers.; 2. In late Greek (as in Macedonian, v. Kennedy, Sources, 15), a narrow road, lane, street: in Polyb., of a road in camp; in LXX and NT (Papyri also) of streets in a town, Mat.6.2, Luk.14.21 Act.9.11; Act.12.10 (cf. Rutherford, NPhr., 488).†

to draw to oneself, hence, to rescue, deliver: c. acc pers., Mat.27.43, 2Pe.2.7; id. seq. ἀπό, Mat.6.13, Luk.11.4 (Rec., R, mg.), 2Ti.4.18; seq. ἐκ, Rom.7.24, 2Co.1.10, Col.1.13, 1Th.1.10, 2Ti.3.11, 2Pe.2.9; absol., ὁ ῥυύμενος, the deliverer, Rom.11.26. Passive: seq. ἀπό, Rom.15.31, 2Th.3.2; seq. ἐκ, Luk.1.74, 2Ti.4.17.†
filthiness: metaph., of moral defile­ment, Jas.1.21.†

filthy, dirty: of old, shabby clothing (Za, l.c.), Jas.2.2; metaph., of moral defilement, Rev.22.11.†; * ῥυπαίνω; in Arist., Xen., and later writers, to make filthy, defile: pass., in ethical sense (on the tense, v. Swete, in l), Rev.22.11 LT, Tr., WH, txt.; *† ῥυπαρεύομαι; = ῥυπαίνομαι, q.v.: Rev.22.11, WH, mg. (nowhere else).†
dirt, filth: 1Pe.3.21.†
to make filthy: Rev.22.11 Rec. (AV, tr. as = ῥυπάω, to be filthy).†
a flowing, issue: τ. αἵματος, Mar.5.25, Luk.8.43-44.†
a wrinkle: Eph.5.27.†
Roman, Latin: Luk.23.38 Rec.†
adv.,; in Latin: Joh.19.20.†
to strengthen; most freq. in pf., ἔρρωμαι, to put forth strength, be strong, hence, often in imperat., ἔρρωσο, ἔρρωσθε, farewell (Lat. vale): Act.15.29; Act.23.30 Rec., R, mg.†
ζαφθανεί; zaphthanei: Mat.27.46
indecl.,; Sabaoth, i.e. hosts or armies (v. DB, l.c.): Rom.9.29 (LXX), Ja 54.†
a keeping sabbath, a sabbath rest: metaph., as in Mishna (Zorell, s.v.), Heb.4.9.†

1. the seventh day of the week, the sabbath; (a) the sing. form -ον, τὸ σ.: Mat.12.8, Mar.2.27, Luk.6.5, al.; ἡ ἡμέρα τοῦ σ. (in LXX, Exo.20.8, al., usually τῶν σ., v. infr.), Luk.13.16; Luk.14.5; ὁδὸς σαββάτου, Act.1.12 (cf. Mat.24.29); dat., of time (τῷ) σ., Luk.6.9; Luk.14.1; ἐν (τῷ) σ., Mat.12.2, Luk.6.7, Joh.5.16, al.; acc, of duration, τὸ σ., Luk.23.56; κατὰ πᾶν σ., Act.13.27; Act.15.21; Act.18.4; pl., σ. τρία, Act.17.2 R, txt. (but v. infr.); (b) as most freq. in LXX (v. Swete, Mk., 17; Thackeray, Gr., 35) the pl. form, τὰ σ. (v. supr. on the Aram. form. There is also an analogy in the names of other festivals, τ. ἐγκαίνια, ἄζυμα, etc.): Mat.28.1, Col.2.16; ἡ ἡμέρα τῶν σ. (Exo.20.8, al.), Luk.4.16, Act.13.14; Act.16.13; dat. pl. (in LXX -τοις, but 1Ma.2.38 as in NT) by metaplasmus (El., § 9, 3), σάββασι, Mat.12.1; Mat.12.5; Mat.12.10-12 Mar.1.21; Mar.2.23; Mar.3.2; Mar.3.4, Luk.4.31; Luk.6.2.; 2. seven days, a week; (a) the sing. form: πρώτη σαββάτσυ, Mar.16.9; δὶς τοῦ σ. (Bl., § 35, 4; 36, 13), Luk.18.12; κατὰ μίαν σαββάτου, 1Co.16.2; pl., σ. τρία, Act.17.2 R, mg. (but v. supr.); (b) the pl. form: ἡ μία τῶν σ. (where the gen. = μετὰ τά; Soph., Lex., 43a), Mat.28.1, Mar.16.2, Luk.24.1, Joh.20.1; Joh.20.19, Act.20.7.
a drag-net, seine: Mat.13.47.†; SYN.: ἀμφίβληστρον G293 (q.v.), δίκτυον G1350.
indecl.; Sadoc, Zadok: Mat.1.14.†

1. prop. (Hom., al.), of dogs, to wag the tail, fawn.; 2. Metaph., of persons, c. acc, to fawn upon, flatter, beguile: pass., 1Th.3.3 (for conjectural emendations of the text, v. ICC, and M, Th., in l).†; ἀσαίνω, see σαίνω.

also written σάκος, -ου, ὁ; 1. a coarse cloth, sackcloth, usually made of hair: Rev.6.12.; 2. Anything made of sackcloth; (a) a sack (Gen.42.25, al.); (b) a garment of sackcloth, expressive of mourning or penitence: Mat.11.21, Luk.10.13, Rev.11.3.†
indecl.
indecl. (Heb. H7597),; Salathiel: Mat.1.12, Luk.3.27.†
Salamis, the chief city of Cyprus: Act.13.5.†
indecl., Salim: Joh.3.23 (v. Westc., in l; DB, iii, 354).†

prop., of the action of wind, storm, etc., to agitate, shake: of a reed, Mat.11.7, Luk.7.24; a house, Luk.6.48, Act.4.31; Act.16.26; the earth, Heb.12.26; the heavenly bodies, Mat.24.29, Mar.13.25, Luk.21.26; of a vessel shaken in filling, Luk.6.38. Metaph.,; (a) to shake, i.e. to render insecure: τὰ σαλευόμενα, τὰ μὴ., Heb.12.27; (b) c. acc pers., to cast down from a sense of security and happiness: Act.2.25 (LXX); (c) to unsettle or drive away: pass., seq. ἀπὸ τ. νοός, 2Th.2.2; (d) to stir up: τ. ὄχλους, Act.17.13.†
Salem: Heb.7.1-2 (LXX).†
indecl.; Salmon: Mat.1.4-5, Luk.3.32 (Σαλά, WH, R, mg.).†
Salmone, a promontory of Crete: Act.27.7.†
in poets and late prose, a tossing, as of an earthquake; esp. the tossing, the rolling swell of the sea: Luk.21.25.†

a trumpet, used in war and in religious ceremonies: 1Co.14.8, Heb.12.19, Rev.1.10; Rev.4.1; Rev.8.2; Rev.8.6; Rev.8.11; Rev.9.14 By meton., a trumpet blast: μετὰ σ. μεγάλης, Mat.24.31; ἐν σ. θεοῦ, 1Th.4.16; ἐν τ. ἐσχάτῃ σ., 1Co.15.52.†
to sound a trumpet: Rev.8.6 ff. Rev.9.1; Rev.9.13; Rev.10.7; Rev.11.15; metaph., Mat.6.2. Impers., the trumpet sounds: 1Co.15.52.†
Salome: Mar.15.40; Mar.16.1.†

Samaria; (a) the city: Act.8.5 (and perhaps also Act.8.9; Act.8.14); (b) the region: Luk.17.11, Joh.4.4-5; Joh.4.7, Act.1.8; Act.8.1 (and perhaps also Act.8.9; Act.8.14) Act.9.31; Act.15.3.†; Σαμάρεια, see Σαμαρία.

a Samaritan, i.e. an inhabitant of the city or the region of Samaria, in NT always the latter (see Σαμαρία): Mat.10.5, Luk.9.52; Luk.10.33; Luk.17.16, Joh.4.9; Joh.4.39-40, Act.8.25; as an opprobrious epithet, Joh.8.48.†
1. in FlJ (B.J., i, 21, 2, al.), the region of Samaria.; 2. a Samaritan woman: Joh.4.9.†
Samothrace, an island in the Ægean: Act.16.11.†
Samos, an island in the Ægean: Act.20.15.†
indecl.; Samuel (1Sa.1.20, al.): Act.3.24; Act.13.20, Heb.11.32.†
indecl.; Samson (Jdg.13.1-25 ff.): Heb.11.32.†
a sandal: Mar.6.9, Act.12.8.†
a board, plank: Act.27.44.
indecl.; Saul; (a) the King of Israel: Act.13.21; (b) the Jewish name of the Apostle Paul, used in the indecl. form only in address (cf. Σαῦλος): Act.9.4; Act.9.17; Act.22.7; Act.22.13; Act.26.14.†

rotten, corrupt, bad, worth­less: of trees and fruit (opp. to ἀγαθός, καλός), Mat.7.17-18; Mat.12.33 Luk.6.43; of fish, Mat.13.48.; Metaph., in moral sense: λόγος σ., Eph.4.29. "In Hellenistic . . . it became a synonym for αἰσχρός or κακός," MM, xxii.†
Sapphia: Act.5.1.†
sapphire (perh. = lapis lazuli): Rev.21.19.†
1. a plaited rope (Æsch.).; 2. a hamper, a basket made of ropes: 2Co.11.33.†
Sardis, the chief city of Lydia: Rev.1.11; Rev.3.1; Rev.3.4.
= σάρδιον (q.v.), Rev.4.3, Rec.†
the sardian stone, sard (of which carnelian is one variety): Rev.4.3; Rev.21.20.†
sardonyx, a stone marked by the red of the sard and the white of the onyx: Rev.21.20.†
Sarepta, a city of Sidon: Luk.4.26.†

= Lat. carnalis, i.e.; (a) associated with or pertaining to the flesh, fleshly, carnal: Rom.15.27, 1Co.9.11; (b) in a more ethical sense, of the nature of the flesh, under the control of its appetites, fleshly, carnal, sensual (but including more than mere sensuality; cf. Hort, 1Pe., 133): 1Co.3.3, 2Co.1.12; 2Co.10.4, 1Pe.2.11.†; SYN.: σάρκινος G4560 (q.v.), ψυχικός G5591; cf. Tr., Syn., §§ LXXi, LXXii; Lft., Notes, 184 f.; Vau. on Rom.7.14.

= Lat. carneus (the termination -ινος denoting the substance or material of a thing; v. Tr., Syn., § LXXii; Lft., Notes, 184; and for illustrations from Papyri, v. MM, xxii), of the flesh, of flesh, fleshy (Plat., Arist., Plut., al.): Rom.7.14, 1Co.3.1, 2Co.3.3, Heb.7.16. (Rec. has -ικός in all these passages except 2Co.3.3, but the evidence is decisive against it.)†; SYN.: σαρκικός G4559, q.v.

flesh; 1. as in cl. generally,; (a) prop., of the soft substance of the animal body: 1Co.15.39, 2Co.12.7, Gal.6.13, al.; σ. καὶ αἷμα, 1Co.15.50; σ. καὶ ὀστέα, Luk.24.39; pl., of the flesh of many or parts of the flesh of one (cl.), Rev.17.16; Rev.19.18 φαγεῖν, Re, ll. C. (cf. κατεσθίειν, 2Ki.9.36, al., and βιβρώσκειν, freq. in ώ.); metaph., Jas.5.3; mystically, φ. (τρώγειν) τὴν σ. τοῦ υἱοῦ τ. ἀνθρώπου, Joh.6.52-56; (b) of the whole substance of the body, = σῶμα: Act.2.26 (LXX) Act.2.31, 2Co.12.7, Gal.4.14, Eph.5.29; μία σ., Mar.10.8; εἰς σ. μίαν (Gen.2.24), Mat.19.5, Mar.10.8, 1Co.6.16, Eph.5.31; hence, of the material as opp. to the immaterial part of man (cf. Lft., Notes, 88): opp. to πνεῦμα, 1Co.5.5, 2Co.7.1, Col.2.5, 1Pe.3.18; 1Pe.4.6; to ψυχή, Act.2.31, Rec.; of the present life, ἐν σ., Rom.7.5, Gal.2.20, Php.1.22; Php.1.24, 1Pe.4.2; of Christ's life on earth, αἱ ἡμέραι τ. σαρκὸς αὐτοῦ, Heb.5.7; of things pertaining to the body, ἐν (τῇ) σ., Gal.6.12-13, Php.3.3-4; 2. As in Heb. idiom,; (a) of a living creature: πᾶσα σ. (Heb. H1320־H3605; cf. El., § 47, 9), Mat.24.22, Mar.13.20, 1Pe.1.24; esp. of man and his mortality (Psa.56.5, Sir.28.5, al.), Joh.1.14; πᾶσα σ. (v. supr.), Luk.3.6, Joh.17.2, Act.2.17; ἐν σ., 1Jn.4.2, 1Ti.3.16; (b) of natural origin and relationship (Gen.2.24, Isa.58.7, al.): τέκνα τῆς σ., Rom.9.8; κατὰ σάρκα, Rom.9.3; Rom.9.5, 1Co.10.18, Gal.4.23; Gal.4.29; ἡ σ. μου, Rom.11.14 (cf. Jdg.9.2, 2Sa.5.1, al.).; 3. Of the physical nature as subject to sensation and desire (Plut.),; (a) without any ethical disparagement: Rom.7.18; Rom.13.14; opp. to πνεῦμα, Mat.26.41, Mar.14.38; τ. θέλημα τῆς σ., Joh.1.13; ἡ ἐπιθυμία τῆς σ., 1Jn.2.16; pl., 2Pe.2.18; πειθεῖν σαρκί, 1Pe.4.1; (b) in ethical sense, esp. in Pauline Epp., of the flesh as the seat and vehicle of sinful desires: opp. to νοῦς, Rom.7.25; to πνεῦμα, Rom.8.4-9; Rom.8.12-13 Gal.5.16-17; Gal.5.19; Gal.6.8 (cf. DB, ii, 14 f.; iv, 165 f.; Cremer, 844 ff.).
indecl.; Serug: Luk.3.35.†; Σαρούχ, see Σερούχ.
late form of σαίρω,; to sweep: c. acc, Luk.15.8; pass., Mat.12.44, Luk.11.25.†
the plain of Sharon: Act.9.35.†

Satan (i.e. the adversary, as in LXX, ll. c.): Mat.4.10; Mat.12.26, Mar.1.13; Mar.3.23; Mar.3.26; Mar.4.15 Luk.10.18; Luk.11.18; Luk.13.16; Luk.22.3; Luk.22.31, Joh.13.27, Act.5.3; Act.26.18, Rom.16.20, 1Co.5.5; 1Co.7.5, 2Co.2.11; 2Co.11.14, 1Th.2.18, 2Th.2.9, 1Ti.1.20; 1Ti.5.15, Rev.2.9; Rev.2.13; Rev.2.24; Rev.3.9; Rev.12.9; Rev.20.2; Rev.20.7; addressed in person of Peter, Mat.16.23 Mar.8.33; ἄγγελος Σατανᾶ, 2Co.12.7.†
a Hebrew measure (= about a peck and a half): Mat.13.33, Luk.13.21.†
Saul, the Jewish name of the Apostle Paul: Act.7.58; Act.8.1; Act.8.3; Act.9.1; Act.9.8; Act.9.11; Act.9.22; Act.9.24; Act.11.25; Act.11.30; Act.12.25; Act.13.1-2; Act.13.7; Act.13.9.†

of fire or things on fire, to quench: c. acc, Mat.12.20, Eph.6.16, Heb.11.34; pass., Mat.25.8, Mar.9.48, [44, 46]. Metaph. (cf. Son.8.7, 4Ma.16.4): τὸ πνεῦμα, 1Th.5.19.†; ζβέννυμι, for σβ-, 1Th.5.19 T (v. WH, Notes, 148).†
1. to fear (Hom).; 2. In later writers, = σέβομαι, to worship: Rom.1.25.
an object of worship: Act.17.23, 2Th.2.4.†

1. reverend, august.; 2. In late writers, with reference to the Roman Imperial name; (a) ὁ Σ., Augustus, i.e. the Roman Emperor: Act.25.21; Act.25.25; (b) Augustan: σπείρα σ., Act.27.1 (See further, Deiss., BS, 218.) †

to worship: c. acc pers., Mat.15.9, Mar.7.7, Act.18.13; Act.19.27; σεβόμενος τ. θεόν, Act.16.14; Act.18.7; σεβόμενοι (σ. προσήλυτοι, σ. Ἕλληνες), devout, Act.13.43; Act.13.50; Act.17.4; Act.17.17 (cf. προσήλυτος).†
1. (a) a cord; (b) a chain (cf. Pr., l.c.): σειραὶ ζόφου, 2Pe.2.4, Rec., R, mg. (see σειρός).; 2. a lock of hair (Jg, ll. c.).†; * σειρός; σιρός, see σειρός.
a shaking, commotion, as a tempest at sea: Mat.8.24; esp. an earthquake: Mat.24.7; Mat.27.54; Mat.28.2, Mar.13.8, Luk.21.11, Act.16.26, Rev.6.12; Rev.8.5; Rev.11.13; Rev.11.19; Rev.16.18.†

to shake, move to and fro: τ. γῆν, Heb.12.26 (LXX); pass., ἡ γῆ, Mat.27.51 (LXX); συκῆ, Rev.6.13. Metaph., to agitate, stir up, with fear or some other emotion: Mat.21.10; Mat.28.4 (cf. ἀνα-, δια-, κατα-σείω).†
Seleucia, a city of Syria: Act.13.4.†
act, in Manetho (Caren., 4, 81), in NT depon. -ομαι, to be moonstruck, i.e. epileptic (epilepsy being supposed to be influenced by the moon): Mat.4.24; Mat.17.15.†
indecl.,; Semein: Luk.3.26.†
fine wheaten flour: Rev.18.13.†

1. reverend, august, venerable, in cl. of the gods and also of human beings.; 2. grave, serious; of persons: 1Ti.3.8; 1Ti.3.11, Tit.2.2; of things: Php.4.8 (v. Tr., Syn., § xcii; Cremer, 37; MM, xxii).†
gravity: 1Ti.2.2; 1Ti.3.4 (Vg. eastitas, cf. Soph., Lex., and Zorell, s.v.), Tit.2.7.†
Sergius, surnamed Paulus: Act.13.7.†
indecl.,; Seth (Gen.4.25): Luk.3.38.†
indecl.
to give a sign, signify, indicate: c. acc rei, Act.25.27, Rev.1.1 (cf. MM, xxii); c. acc et inf., Act.11.28; seq. quæst. indir., Joh.12.33; Joh.18.32; Joh.21.19.†

a sign, mark, token; (a) of that which distinguishes a person or thing from others: Mat.26.48 Luk.2.12, 2Th.3.17 (cf. Deiss., LAE, 153.2); seq. gen. epexeg., Rom.4.11; c. gen. obj., Mat.24.8; Mat.24.30, 2Co.12.12; c. gen. subj., Mat.16.3; (b) a sign of warning or admonition: Mat.12.39; Mat.16.4, Luk.2.34; Luk.11.29-30, 1Co.14.22; (c) a sign portending future events (Soph., Plat. al.): Mar.13.4, Luk.21.7; Luk.21.11; Luk.21.25, Act.2.19, Rev.12.1; Rev.12.3; Rev.15.1; (d) of miracles and wonders (MM, xxii), regarded as signs of a divine authority: Mat.12.38-39; Mat.16.1; Mat.16.4 Mar.8.11-12 Luk.11.16; Luk.11.29; Luk.23.8, Joh.2.11; Joh.2.18; Joh.2.23; Joh.4.54; Joh.6.30; Joh.10.41; Joh.12.18, Act.4.16; Act.4.22; pl., Mar.16.17; Mar.16.20, Joh.2.11; Joh.2.23; Joh.3.2; Joh.6.2; Joh.6.14; Joh.6.26; Joh.7.31; Joh.9.16; Joh.11.47; Joh.12.37; Joh.20.30, Act.8.6, 1Co.1.22 (Lft., Notes, 162); the same ascribed to false teachers and demons: Mat.24.24, Mar.13.22, 2Th.2.9, Rev.13.13-14; Rev.16.14; Rev.19.20; σ. καὶ τέρατα (τ. καὶ σ.; cf. Tr., Syn., § xci), Mat.24.24, Mar.13.22, Joh.4.48, Act.2.19; Act.2.43; Act.4.30; Act.5.12; Act.6.8; Act.7.36; Act.14.3; Act.15.12, Rom.15.19, 2Th.2.9; id. seq. καὶ δυνάμεις, 2Co.12.12, Heb.2.4; σ. καὶ δυνάμεις, Act.8.13; δ. καὶ τ. καὶ σ., Act.2.22; σ. διδόναι, Mat.24.24, Mar.13.22.†
to mark, note. Mid., to note for oneself: 2Th.3.14 (freq. in Papyri; v. ICC, M, Th., in l).†

adv.,; to-day: Mat.6.11, Luk.4.21, Act.4.9, al.; opp. to αὔριον, Mat.6.30, Luk.12.28, Jas.4.13; χθὲς καὶ σ. καὶ εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας, Heb.13.8; ἡ σ. ἡμέρα, Act.20.20; ἕως (ἄχρι) τῆς σ. ἡμέρας, Rom.11.8, 2Co.3.14; μέχρι (ἕως) τῆς σ. (sc. ἡμέρας), Mat.11.23; Mat.27.8; as subst., τὸ σ., Heb.3.13; id. in appos., ὁρίζει ἡμὶραν, σ., Heb.4.7 R, mg., (v. Westc., in l).
to make corrupt: 2 pf. act, with mid, sense (v. M, Pr., 154), σέσηπεν, has perished, become corrupted, Jas.5.2.†
silk, silken; as subst., τὸ σ., silken fabric, silk: Rev.18.12 (cf. FlJ, B.J., vii, 5, 4).†; σηρικός, see σιρικός.
σητός; a moth, clothes moth: Mat.6.19-20, Luk.12.33.†
moth-eaten: Jas.5.2.†
to strengthen: c. acc., 1Pe.5.10 (Hesych.).†
the jawbone, jaw, cheek: Mat.5.39, Luk.6.29 (cf. MM, xxii).†

1. intrans., to be silent, keep silence: Luk.9.36; Luk.18.39; Luk.20.26, Act.12.17; Act.15.12-13, 1Co.14.28; 1Co.14.30; 1Co.14.34.; 2. Trans., to keep secret; pass., to be kept secret: Rom.16.25.†; SYN.: ἡσυχάζω, σιωπάω.
silence: Act.21.40, Rev.8.1.†
iron: Rev.18.12.†
Sidon, a maritime city of Phœnicia: Mat.11.21-22; Mat.15.21, Mar.3.8; Mar.7.24; Mar.7.31, Luk.6.17; Luk.10.13-14, Act.27.3.†
of Sidon, Sidonian; (a) the region: sc. χώρα, Luk.4.26; (b) the people: Act.12.20.†
a bandit, assassin, one of the Sicarii (FlJ, B.J., ii, 17, 6, al.): Act.21.38.†
indecl.; fermented liquor, strong drink: Luk.1.15.†
Silas (called also Σιλουανός, q.v.): Act.15.22; Act.15.27; Act.15.32; Act.15.34; Act.15.40; Act.16.19; Act.16.25; Act.16.29; Act.17.4; Act.17.10; Act.17.14-15; Act.18.5 †
Silvanus, latinized name of Silas: 2Co.1.19, 1Th.1.1, 2Th.1.1, 1Pe.5.12.†
Siloam (v. DB, iii, 515 f.): Luk.13.4, Joh.9.7; Joh.9.11.†
a work­man's apron: Act.19.12.†

a Greek name (transliterated סִימוֺן in Heb.) used as a substitute for Συμεών (q.v.), Simon; 1. Simon Peter: Mat.17.25, Mar.1.29, al.; 2. Simon the Zealot (see ζηλωτής, Καναναῖος): Mat.10.4, Mar.3.18, Luk.6.15, Act.1.13.; 3. One of the Brethren of our Lord (see ἀδελψός): Mat.13.55, Mar.6.3.; 4. The father of Judas Iscariot, himself surnamed Ἰσκαριώτης (q.v.): Joh.6.71; Joh.12.4 (Rec.) 13:2,26; 5. Simon the Cyrenian: Mat.27.32, Mar.15.21, Luk.23.26.; 6. Simon the Pharisee: Luk.7.40; Luk.7.43-44.; 7. Simon of Bethany, surnamed ὁ λεπρός: Mat.26.6, Mar.14.3.; 8. Simon Magus, a Samaritan sorcerer: Act.8.9; Act.8.13; Act.8.18; Act.8.24.; 9. Simon the tanner, of Joppa: Act.9.43; Act.10.6; Act.10.17; Act.10.32.
indecl. (but τὸ Σιναῖον, FlJ, Ant., iii, 5, 1; τὸ Σιναῖον ὄρος, ib. ii, 12, 1), τό; Sinai (Exo.19.11, al.): Act.7.30; Act.7.38, Gal.4.24-25†
fine linen cloth; (a) as used for swathing dead bodies (cf. Hdt., ii, 86): Mat.27.59, Mar.15.46, Luk.23.53; (b) a garment or wrap of this material (cf. ICC, Jg, l.c.): Mar.14.51-52.†
to sift, winnow: fig., Luk.22.31.†
fattened: Luk.15.23; Luk.15.27; Luk.15.30.†
= σιτευτός, fattened; as subst., pl., τὰ σ., fatlings: Mat.22.4.†
a measured portion of food: Luk.12.42 (for exx. in Papyri, v. Deiss., BS, 158; LAE, 103.1).†

wheat, corn: Mat.3.12; Mat.13.25; Mat.13.29-30 Mar.4.28, Luk.3.17; Luk.12.18; Luk.16.7; Luk.22.32, Joh.12.24, Act.27.38, 1Co.15.37, Rev.6.6; Rev.18.13.†; σιτίοι, -ου, τό; 1. corn, grain: Act.7.12 (but v. 131., § 9, 1).; 2. Mostly in pl., σιτία, bread, food, provisions (LXX, l.c., Hdt., al.).†

indecl.,; in NT anarth., but in LXX when used of the city of Jerusalem, ἡ Σ.; Zion; 1. the mountain: in typical sense, of the Church, Heb.12.22; of heaven, Rev.14.1.; 2. The city, i.e. Jerusalem; in poetical sense; (a) of the inhabitants: θυγάτηρ Σ, Mat.21.5, Joh.12.15 (LXX); (b) in wider sense, of Israel: Rom.11.26; (c) fig.: τίθήμι ἐν Σ λίθον, Rom.9.33, 1Pe.2.6 (LXX).†

to be silent or still, keep silence: Mat.20.31; Mat.26.63, Mar.3.4; Mar.9.34; Mar.10.48; Mar.14.61, Luk.19.4 , Act.18.9; of one dumb, Luk.1.20 (cf. 4Ma.10.18); addressed rhetorically to the sea, σιώπα, Mar.4.39.†; SYN.: ἡσυχάζω G2270, σιγάω G4601 (q.v.).

prop., to put a snare or stumbling-block in the way; in NT always metaph. of that which hinders right conduct or thought, to cause to stumble: c. acc pers., Mat.5.29-30; Mat.17.27; Mat.18.6; Mat.18.8-9 Mar.9.42-43; Mar.9.45; Mar.9.47 Luk.17.2, Joh.6.61, 1Co.8.13. Pass., to be made to stumble, to stumble: Mat.11.6; Mat.13.21; Mat.13.57; Mat.15.12; Mat.24.10; Mat.26.31; Mat.26.33, Mar.4.17; Mar.6.3; Mar.14.27; Mar.14.29, Luk.7.23, Joh.16.1, Rom.14.21 (WH, R, txt., om.), 2Co.11.29,†

prop.,; the bait-stick of a trap, a snare, stumbling-block (Lev.19.14, Jdt.5.1): fig., Rom.9.33, 1Pe.2.8 (Isa.8.14; aliter in LXX; στερεὸν σκανδάλου in Aq.). Metaph., of that which causes error or sin; (a) of persons: Mat.13.41; Mat.16.23; Χριστὸς ἐσταυρωμένος, 1Co.1.23; (b) of things: Mat.18.7, Rom.11.9 (LXX) Rom.14.13, 1Jn.2.10 Rev.2.14; τὸ σ. τοῦ σταυροῦ, Gal.5.11; pl., Mat.18.7, Luk.17.1, Rom.16.17.†; SYN.: πρόσκομμα G4348.
to dig: Luk.6.48; Luk.13.8; Luk.16.3.†
anything scooped out, esp. a light boat, skiff: Act.27.16; Act.27.30; Act.27.32.†
the leg from the hip downwards: ?Joh.19.3-33 †
a covering, esp. clothing: 1Ti.6.8.†
Sceva: Act.19.14.†
equipment, tackle: Act.27.19.†

a vessel, implement (for exx. in various senses, v. MM, xxii): Mar.11.16, Luk.8.16, Joh.19.29, Act.10.11; Act.10.16; Act.11.5, Rom.9.21, Rev.18.12; pl., 2Ti.2.20, Rev.2.27; τὰ σ. τῆς λειτουργίας, Heb.9.21; pl., τὰ σ., utensils, goods, Mat.12.29, Mar.3.27, Luk.17.31; id. of the tackle or gear of a ship (Xen., Polyb., al.); so in sing., τὸ σ., Act.27.17. Metaph., of persons: σ. ἐκλογῆς, Act.9.15; ὀργῆς, Rom.9.22; ἐλέους, Rom.9.23; σ. εἰς τιμήν (cf. Rom.9.21), 2Ti.2.21; of woman, ἀσθενέστερον σ., 1Pe.3.7; so perh. τ. ἑαυτοῦ σ., 1Th.4.4 (but v. infr.); of the body, 2Co.4.7; so perh. 1Th.4.4 (but v. supr., and see κτάομαι).†

a tent, booth, tabernacle: Mat.17.4, Mar.9.5, Luk.9.33, Heb.11.9; αἱ αἰώνιοι σ., Luk.16.9; of the Mosaic tabernacle, Heb.8.5; Heb.9.2-3; Heb.9.6; Heb.9.8; Heb.9.21; σ. τ. μαρτυρίου, Act.7.44; of its heavenly prototype, Heb.8.2; Heb.9.11, Rev.13.6; Rev.15.5; Rev.21.3; of the temple, Heb.13.10; ἡ σ. τοῦ Μολόχ, Act.7.43 (LXX); metaph., ἡ σ. Δαυείδ Act.15.16 (LXX).†
prop.,; the setting up of tents or dwellings (Arist.); in LXX and NT, ἡ σ., ἡ ἑορτή τῆς σ. (called also ἑορτὴ σκηνῶν, Lev.23.34, al.; v. Deiss., LAE, 116 f.), the feast of Tabernacles: Joh.7.2.†
making tents; as subst., ὁ σ., a tent-maker: Act.18.3.†
= σκηνή,; a tent, tabernacle (C.1., 3071). Metaph., of the body as the tabernacle of the soul: 2Co.5.1; 2Co.5.4.†

to have one's tabernacle, to dwell (in Papyri of temporary dwelling, v. MM, Exp., xxii): seq. ἐπί, c. acc pers., Rev.7.15; seq. ἐν, c. dat. pers., Joh.1.14; id. c. dat. loc., Rev.12.12; Rev.13.6; seq. μετά, c. gen. pers., Rev.21.3 (cf. ἐπι-, κατα-σκηνόω).†
a tent, tabernacle (cf. σκηνή, σκῆνος): of the temple as God's dwelling (Psa.132.5, al.), Act.7.46. Metaph., of the body: 2Pe.1.13-14.†

1. shadow, shade, caused by interception of light: Mar.4.32, Act.5.15; metaph., σ. θανάτου, of ignorance and error, Mat.4.16, Luk.1.79 (LXX).; 2. a shadow, the image or outline cast by an object: fig., ὑπόδειγμα καὶ σ., Heb.8.5; opp. to σῶμα, Col.2.17; opp. to εἰκών, Heb.10.1.†
to leap: Luk.1.41; Luk.1.44; Luk.6.23.†
hardness of heart: Mat.19.8, Mar.10.5; Mar.16.14.†

hard to the touch, rough, harsh, (opp. to μαλακός); metaph., in various uses; (a) of men, hard, stern, severe: Mat.25.24; (b) of things, hard, rough, violent: σκληρόν σοι (ἐστι), Act.26.14; λόγος, Joh.6.60; ἄνεμος, Jas.3.4; σκληρὰ λαλεῖν, Jud.1.15.†; SYN.: αὐστηρός G840, q.v.
hardness; metaph., of stubbornness: Rom.2.5.†
stiff-necked: metaph., Act.7.51.†
to harden. Metaph., to harden, make stubborn: c. acc pers., Rom.9.18; T. καρδίας (Psa.95.8), Heb.3.8; Heb.3.15; Heb.4.7. Pass., to become hardened: Act.19.9, Heb.3.13.†
curved, bent, winding (opp. to ὀρθός, εὐθύς): Luk.3.5 (LXX). Metaph., crooked, perverse, unjust: Act.2.40, Php.2.15, 1Pe.2.18.†
anything pointed, esp.; 1. in cl., a stake.; 2. In Hellenistic vernacular, a thorn (cf. LXX, ll. c.): σ. τῇ σαρκί, 2Co.12.7.

to look at, behold, watch, contemplate. Metaph., to look to, consider: c. acc rei, 2Co.4.13, Php.2.4; c. acc pers., Rom.16.17, Php.3.17; seq. μή, Luk.11.35; σεαυτόν, seq. μή (v. M, Pr., 192), Gal.6.1 (cf. ἐπι-, κατα-σκοπέω).†; SYN.: βλέπω G991, θεωρέω G2334, ὁράω G3708.
1. a watcher, watchman (Eze.3.17, al.).; 2. a mark on which to fix the eye (Wis.5.12; Wis.5.21, al.). Metaph., of an aim or object: Php.3.14.†

in vernac. and in Ion, and late writers for σκεδάννυμι (v. MM, xxiii; Rutherford, NPhr., 295), to scatter: ὁ λύκος, Joh.10.12; ὁ μὴ συνάγων μετ᾿ ἐμοῦ σκορπίζει, Mat.12.30, Luk.11.23; pass., seq. εἰς, c. acc loc., Joh.16.32; of one who dispenses blessings, 2Co.9.9 (LXX) (of. δια-σκορπίζομαι).†
a scorpion: Luk.10.19; Luk.11.12, Rev.9.3; Rev.9.5; Rev.9.10 †
dark: opp. to φωτεινός, Mat.6.23, Luk.11.34; Luk.11.36.†

in late writers = σκότος,; darkness: Joh.6.17; Joh.20.1. Metaph.,; (a) of secrecy (opp. to ἐν τ. φωτί): Mat.10.27, Luk.12.3; (b) of spiritual darkness: Mat.4.16, Joh.1.5; Joh.8.12; Joh.12.35; Joh.12.40, 1Jn.1.5; 1Jn.2.8-9; 1Jn.2.11.†
to darken; in NT always pass., -ομαι, to be darkened: of the heavenly bodies, Mat.24.29, Mar.13.24, Luk.23.45 (Rec., WH, mg.), Rev.8.12. Metaph., of the mind, Rom.1.21; Rom.11.10 (LXX) (cf. σκοτόω).†

the more usual cl. form (cf.σ., τό),; darkness: Heb.12.18, Rec.†; σκότος, -ους, τό,; a form rare in cl. (cf. ὁ σ.) but freq. in LXX,; darkness: Mat.27.45, Mar.15.33, Luk.22.53; Luk.23.44, Act.2.20, 2Co.4.6; τὰ κρυπτὰ τοῦ σ., 1Co.4.5; of blindness, Mat.6.23, Act.13.11; by meton., of a dark place, Mat.8.12; Mat.22.13; Mat.25.30, 2Pe.2.17, Jud.1.13. Metaph., of moral and spiritual darkness: Luk.11.35, Joh.3.19, Act.26.18, 2Co.6.14, Eph.6.12, Col.1.13, 1Pe.2.9; by meton., of those who are in spiritual darkness, Eph.5.8; τ. ἔργα τοῦ σ., Rom.13.12, Eph.5.11; οκότους εἶναι, 1Th.5.5; ἐν σ. εἶναι, 1Th.5.4; οἱ ἐν σ., Luk.1.79, Rom.2.19; ὁ λαὸς ὁ καθήμενος ἐν σ., Mat.4.16 (LXX) (WH. οκοτίᾳ); ἐν σ. περιπατεῖν, 1Jn.1.6.†
to darken: Rev.9.2; Rev.16.10. Metaph., of the mind! pass., Eph.4.18 (cf. σκοτίζω).†
refuse, esp. dung (v. MM, ii, iii, xxiii): Php.3.8.†
Scythian, an inhabitant of Scythia, i.e. Russia and Siberia, a synonym with the Greeks for the wildest of barbarians: Col.3.11.†
of a gloomy countenance: Mat.6.16, Luk.24.17.†

1. in cl., to skin, flay, rend (Æsch., Anthol.).; 2. In Hellenistic writers, to vex, trouble, annoy: c. acc pers., Mar.5.35, Luk.8.49; pass., ἐσκυλμένοι, distressed, Mat.9.36; mid., to trouble oneself, μὴ σκύλλου, Luk.7.6 (freq. in Papyri; v. MM, i, ii, and cf. M, Pr., 89; Abbott, Essays, 87; Kennedy, Sources, 82).†
mostly in pl., σκίλα, arms stripped from a foe, spoils: Luk.11.22.†
eaten of worms: Act.12.23 (cf. 2Ma.9.9, and v. MM, xxiii) †
a worm: of the kind which preys upon dead bodies, metaph., of fut. punishment, Mar.9.48 (LXX, Isa.66.24; cf. Sir.7.17, Jdt.16.17).†
1. of emerald (Luc., V.H., ii, 11).; 2. As in Papyri (Deiss., BS, 267), emerald-green: Rev.4.3 (for the construction, v. Swete, in l; Zorell, s.v.).†
emerald or other trans parent green stone (LS, s.v.; DB, iv, 620; Swete, Ap., 67, 288): Rev.21.19.†
myrrh, a resinous gum used as an unguent and for em­balming: Mat.2.11, Joh.19.39.†
Smyrna, an Ionian city on the Ægean: Rev.1.11; Rev.2.8.†; Ζμύρνα, -ης, ἡ,; Rev.1.11; Rev.2.8 T, for Σμ-, q.v. (cf. B1., § 3, 9; Mayser, 204).†
of Smyrna: Rev.2.8, Rec.†
1. intrans., to be like myrrh (Diosc., i, 79).; 2. Trans., to mingle or drug with myrrh: pass., Mar.15.23.†
(a) a cinerary urn (Hom.); (b) a coffin (Hdt., i, 68, 3, a1.): Luk.7.14.†
possess. prop. of second pers.,; thy, thine: Mat.7.3, al.; as subst., οἱ σοί, thy kinsfolk, friends, Mar.5.19; τὸ σόν, what is thine, Mat.20.14; Mat.25.25; τὰ σά, thy goods, Luk.6.30.
handkerchief, kerchief: Luk.19.20, Act.19.12; used as a head covering for the dead, Joh.11.44; Joh.20.7 (cf. Deiss., BS, 223).†
Susanna: Luk.8.3.†

skill, intelligence, wisdom, ranging from knowledge of the arts and matters of daily life to mental excellence in its highest and fullest sense; (a) of human wisdom: 1Co.2.1; 1Co.2.4-5, Jas.3.15, Rev.13.18; Rev.17.9; σ. Σολομῶνος, Mat.12.42, Luk.11.31; Αἰγυπτίων, Act.7.22; Ἕλληνες σ. ζητοῦσιν, 1Co.1.22; σ. λόγου, 1Co.1.17; τ. σοφῶν, 1Co.1.19 (LXX); τ. κόσμου, 1Co.1.20-21; 1Co.3.19; ἀνθρωπίνη, 1Co.2.13; σαρκική, 2Co.1.12; of wisdom in spiritual things: Luk.21.15, Act.6.3; Act.6.10; Act.7.10, 1Co.2.6, Col.1.28; Col.2.23; Col.3.16; Col.4.5, Jas.1.5; Jas.3.13; Jas.3.17, 2Pe.3.15; λόγος σοφίας, 1Co.12.8; πνεῦμα σοφίας, Eph.1.17; σ. καὶ φρόνησις, Eph.1.8; σ. καὶ σύνεσις, Col.1.9; (b) of divine wisdom: of God, Rom.11.33, 1Co.1.21; 1Co.1.24; 1Co.2.7, Rev.7.12; πολυποίκιλος, Eph.3.10; of Christ, Mat.13.54, Mar.6.2, Luk.2.40; Luk.2.52, 1Co.1.30 Col.2.3, Rev.5.12; of wisdom personified, Mat.11.19, Luk.7.35; Luk.11.49.†; SYN.: σύνεσις G4907, intelligence; φρόνησις G5428, prudence, which with σ. make up (Arist., N. Eth., i, 13) the three intellectual ἀρεταί. σ. is wisdom primary and absolute; in distinction from which φ. is practical, σύνεσις critical, both being applications of σ. in detail (cf. Lft., and ICC on Col.1.9; Lft., Notes, 317 f.; Tr., Syn., § LXXv; Cremer, 870 ff.).

to make wise, instruct: c. acc pers., 2Ti.3.15 (cf. Psa.19.8 (Psa.119.98). As depon., -ομαι; (a) intrans., to become wise (1Ki.4.27 (1Ki.5.11), Ecc.2.15, and freq. in Sir.7.5, al.); (b) trans., to invent, devise cleverly: pass., 2Pe.1.16

skilled, clever, wise, whether in handicraft, the affairs of life, the sciences or learning: Rom.16.19, 1Co.3.10; of the learned, Rom.1.14; Rom.1.22, 1Co.1.19-20; 1Co.1.26-27; 1Co.3.18-20; of Jewish teachers, Mat.11.25, Luk.10.21; Christian, Mat.23.34; of those en­dowed with practical wisdom, 1Co.6.5, Eph.5.15, Jas.3.13; of God, Rom.16.27; compar., τ. μωρὸν τ. θεοῦ σοφώτερον, 1Co.1.25.†; SYN.: συνετός G4908, φρόνιμος G5429 (see σοφία G4678, SYN.).
Spain: Rom.15.24; Rom.15.28.†
1. to tear, rend, mangle.; 2. to convulse: Mar.1.26 (v. Swete, in l) Mar.9.26, Luk.9.39
to swathe, wrap in swaddling-clothes: Luk.2.7; Luk.2.12 (Hipp., Arist., Plut.).†
to live riotously: 1Ti.5.6, Jas.5.5 (Polyb.).†; SYN.: στρηνιάω G4763, τρυφάω G5171 (v. Tr., Syn., § liv).
in cl. poët. for ἕλκω; mostly used in mid. (cf. M, Pr., 157),; to draw: μάχαιραν, Mar.14.47, Act.16.27,†

1. (= Lat. spira) anything wound or rolled up, a coil.; 2. As a military term used (by Polyb. and later writers) of a body of soldiers, a maniple (third part of a cohort) or cohort (v. Swete, Mk., 375; Westc., Jo., 251 f.): Mat.27.27, Mar.15.16, Joh.18.3; Joh.18.12, Act.10.1; Act.21.31; Act.27.1.†

to sow (seed): absol., Mat.6.26; Mat.13.3-4; Mat.13.18; Mat.25.24; Mat.25.26, Mar.4.3-4, Luk.8.5; Luk.12.24, Joh.4.36, 2Co.9.10; c. acc rei, Mat.13.24; Mat.13.27; Mat.13.37; Mat.13.39, Mar.4.32, Luk.8.5, 1Co.15.36-37; seq. εἰς, Mat.13.22, Mar.4.18; ἐν, Mat.13.24; Mat.13.31; ἐπί, c. gen., Mar.4.31; ἐπί, c. acc, Mat.13.20; Mat.13.23, Mar.4.16; Mar.4.20; παρά, c. acc, Mat.13.19. Metaph.: 1Co.9.11; 1Co.15.42-44, Gal.6.7-8, Jas.3.18; in proverbial sayings, Mat.25.24; Mat.25.26, Luk.19.21-22, Joh.4.37, 2Co.9.6, Gal.6.7; in interpretation of parables, Mat.13.19-23 Mar.4.14-20 †; * ἐπι-οπείρω,; to sow upon or besides: ἀνὰ μέσον, Mat.13.25.†
1. prop., a spy or scout.; 2. An executioner: Mar.6.27 (v. Swete, in l).†

to pour out as a drink-offering, make a libation; pass., fig., σπένδομαι, I am poured out or offered as a libation (in the shedding of my life-blood): Php.2.17 (v. Lft., in l), 2Ti.4.6 (for exx. from Papyri, v. Milligan, Selections, 114 f.; MM, xxiii).†

seed; (a) of plants: Mat.13.24; Mat.13.27; Mat.13.37-38, 2Co.9.10; pl., Mat.13.32, Mar.4.31, 1Co.15.33; metaph., of an escaping remnant (H8300, Isa.1.9; cf. Wis.14.6; Plat., Tim., 23c; FlJ, Ant., xi, 5, 3), Rom.9.29; (b) of men (as γονή; Lat. semen genitale; so in cl.; cf. in LXX, Lev.15.16, al.): Heb.11.11; metaph., of the divine influence, 1Jn.3.9; by meton. (as freq. in poets), seed, offspring, posterity: Mat.22.24-25, Mar.12.19-22, Luk.1.55; Luk.20.28 (LXX) Joh.7.42; Joh.8.33; Joh.8.37 Act.3.25; Act.7.5-6; Act.13.23, Rom.1.3; Rom.4.13; Rom.4.18; Rom.9.7-8; Rom.11.1, 2Co.11.22, Gal.3.16; Gal.3.19, 2Ti.2.8, Heb.2.16; Heb.11.18; pl. (FlJ, Ant., viii, 7, 6; Flat., Leg., ix, 853 c; 4Ma.18.1; in Ga, l.c., contrasted with sing., v. Lft., in l; Milligan, NTD, 105 f.), Gal.3.16; of spiritual offspring, Rom.4.16; Rom.4.18; Rom.9.8, Gal.3.29, Rev.12.17.†
a seed picker; (a) prop., of birds (Arist., Aristoph, al.); (b) in Attic slang, of an idler who lives on scraps picked up in the agora; hence, as subst., ὁ σ., an idle babbler: Act.17.18.†

1. most freq. intrans., to hasten: c. inf. (as freq. in cl.), Act.20.16; ptcp. c. indic., Luk.2.16; c. imperat., Luk.19.5-6; σπεῦσον κ. ἔξελθε, Act.22.18; 2. Trans., c. acc; (a) to hasten, urge on, accelerate (as Hom., Od., xix, 137; Eur., Med., 152; Sir.33.8 (Sir.36.8): 2Pe.3.12, R, mg. (cf. Mayor and ICC, in l, but v. infr.); (b) to desire eagerly (find., Pyth., iii, 110; Eur., Suppl., 161; Isa 165): 2Pe, l.c., R, txt. (but v. supr.).†
a cave, cavern: Joh.11.38, Heb.11.38, Heb.6.15; σ. (EV, den) λῃστῶν (Joh.7.11), Mat.21.13, Mar.11.17, Luk.19.46.†

1. poët. in cl., a rock or reef over which the sea dashes (Polyb., FlJ, al.). Metaph., of men whose conduct causes danger to others, Jud.1.12, R, txt. (but v. infr.).; 2. In late writers = σπίλος (q.v.), a spot, stain; metaph., Ju, l.c., R, mg. (cf. Mayor, 41, but v. supr.).†
to stain, spot, defile: c. acc, Jas.3.6, Jud.1.23.†

1. a rock, cliff (Arist., al.).; 2. In late writers = Att.. κηλίς (v. Rutherford, NPhr., 87 f.), a spot, stain; metaph.,; (a) of moral blemish: Eph.5.27; (b) of riotous and lascivious persons (cf. Dion. Hal., quoted by Mayor, in l): 2Pe.2.13.†

to be moved as to the σπλάγχνα (q.v.), hence, to feel pity or compassion: absol., Luk.10.33; Luk.15.20; ptcp., σπλαγχνισθείς, c. indic., Mat.18.27; Mat.20.34, Mar.1.41; seq. ἐπί, c. dat. pers., Mat.14.14, Luk.7.13; ἐπί, c. acc, Mat.15.32, Mar.6.34; Mar.8.2; Mar.9.22; ωερί, Mat.9.36.

mostly (in NT always) in pl., σπλάγχνα, -ων, τά,; the inward parts (heart, liver, lungs, etc.; Lat. viscera): Act.1.18. Metaph., of the seat of the feelings and of the feelings themselves (in Gk. poets, of anger, anxiety, etc.), the heart, affections (the characteristic LXX and NT reference of the word to feelings of kindness, benevolence and pity, is found in Papyri; v. MM, xxiii; cf. Lft. on Php.1.8): 2Co.6.12; 2Co.7.15, Phm.1.7; Phm.1.12; Phm.1.20, 1Jn.3.17; σ. οἰκτιρμοῦ, Col.3.12; σ. καὶ οἰκτιρμοὶ, Php.2.1; σ. ἐλέους θεοῦ; ἡμῶν, Luk.1.78; σ. Χριστοῦ Ἰησοῦ, Php.1.8.†
a sponge: Mat.27.48, Mar.15.36, Joh.19.29.†
ashes: Heb.9.13; ἐν σάκκῳ καὶ σ. (Isa.58.5, Joh.3.6, Da LXX Dan.9.3, al.), Mat.11.21, Luk.10.13.†
1. a sowing.; 2. seedtime.; 3. seed sown (of human offspring, Soph., Tr., 316, 420): 1Pe.1.23
fit for sowing, sown; as subst., τὰ σ., corn-fields: Mat.12.1, Mar.2.23, Luk.6.1.†
= σπορά,; 1. sowing or seedtime.; 2. seed sown (so usually in late Gk.): Mar.4.26-27, Luk.8.5; Luk.8.11, 2Co.9.10 a (LTr.); metaph., of almsgiving, 2Co.9.10 b.†

to make haste; hence, to be zealous or eager, to give diligence: c. inf. (v. M, Pr., 205 f.), Gal.2.10, Eph.4.3, 1Th.2.17, 2Ti.2.15; 2Ti.4.9; 2Ti.4.21, Tit.3.12, Heb.4.11, 2Pe.1.10; 2Pe.3.14; c. acc et inf. (on this construction v. Mayor in l; MM, xxiii), 2Pe.1.15 (for other constructions v. LS, s.v.).†
in haste; hence, zealous, eager, diligent, earnest: seq. ἐν, 2Co.8.22; compar., -οτεροσς 2Co.8.17 (here in superl. sense, v. Bl., § 44, 3) 2Co.8.22.†

1. with haste or zeal, i.e. earnestly, zealously, diligently: Luk.7.4, 2Ti.1.17, Tit.3.13; compar., -οτέρως, Php.2.28 (RV, Lft., Weymouth, al., but v. infr.).; 2. hastily, speedily: compar., -οτέρως, Php.2.28 (Thayer, Zorell, s.v.; ICC, in l, al., but v. supr.).†

1. haste, speed: μετὰ σ. (Wis.19.2), Mar.6.25, Luk.1.39.; 2. zeal, diligence, earnestness: Rom.12.11, 2Co.7.11-12; 2Co.8.7-8; ἐν σ., Rom.12.8 (v. M, Pr, 104); seq. ὑπέρ, 2Co.8.16; σπουδὴν ἐνδείκνυσθαι, Heb.6.11; σ. παρεισφέρειν, 2Pe.1.5; πᾶσαν σ. ποιεῖσθαι, Jud.1.3 (v. MM, xxiii; M, Pr., 214; Deiss., BS, 361, 364).†
a flexible mat-basket for carrying provisions: Mat.15.37; Mat.16.10, Mar.8.8; Mar.8.20 Act.9.25 (see κόφινος).†; σπυρίς, see σφυρίς.

pl., στάδια (Joh.6.19, T), and metapl., στάδιοι (v. B1., 9, 1),; a stadium, i.e.; 1. a measure of length = 600 Greek feet or ⅛ of a Roman mile Mat.14.24 (Rec., WH, txt., R, mg.), Luk.24.13, Joh.6.19; Joh.11.18, Rev.14.20; Rev.21.16, and, this being the length of the Olympic course,; 2. a race-course: 1Co.9.24.†
prop.,; an earthen jar for racking off wine, hence, generally, a jar: Heb.9.4.†

1. a standing, place, status: σ. ἔχειν (Polyb., v, 5, 3; and cf. Lat. locum habere), Heb.9.8.; 2. insurrection, sedition: Mar.15.7, Luk.23.19; Luk.23.25, Act.19.40; Act.24.5.; 3. In poets and late prose, strife, dissension (cf. MM, xxiii) Act.15.2; Act.23.7; Act.23.10.†
a stater; (a) a weight; (b) a coin (used by late writers of the Greek τετράδραχμον): Mat.17.27; Mat.26.16, WH, mg.†

1. an upright pale or stake (Hom., Hdt., Thuc., al.).; 2. In late writers (Diod., Plut., al.) of the Roman instrument of crucifixion, the Cross: of the Cross on which Christ suffered, Mat.27.32; Mat.27.40; Mat.27.42, Mar.15.21; Mar.15.30; Mar.15.32, Luk.23.26, Joh.19.17; Joh.19.19; Joh.19.25; Joh.19.31, Col.2.14, Heb.12.2; θάνατος σταυροῦ, Php.2.8; τ. αἷμα τοῦ σ., Col.1.20. Metaph., in proverbial sayings: αἴρειν (λαμβάνειν, βαστάζειν) τὸν σ., Mat.10.38; Mat.16.24, Mar.8.34; Mar.10.21, Mar.15.21, Luk.9.23; Luk.14.27 (for an interesting ex. of metaph. use in Papyri, v. MM, xxiii) By meton., for Christ's death on the Cross: 1Co.1.17, Gal.5.11; Gal.6.12; Gal.6.14, Eph.2.16, Php.3.18; ὁ λόγος ὁ τοῦ σ., 1Co.1.18.†

1. to fence with pales, impalisade (Thuc.).; 2. In late writers (Polyb., FlJ; but ἀνασταυρόω is more common) to crucify: c. acc pers., Mat.20.19; Mat.23.34; Mat.26.2; Mat.27.22 ff. Mat.28.5, Mar.15.16 ff. Mar.16.6, Luk.23.21; Luk.23.23; Luk.23.33; Luk.24.7; Luk.24.20, Joh.19.6 ff., Act.2.36; Act.4.10, 1Co.1.13; 1Co.1.23; 1Co.2.2; 1Co.2.8, 2Co.13.4, Gal.3.1, Rev.11.8; metaph., Gal.5.24; Gal.6.14.†

a bunch of grapes: Mat.7.16, Luk.6.44, Rev.14.18. "σ. is properly the ripe grape-cluster as opp. to ὄμφαξ, cf. Gen.40.10, Job.15.33; as contrasted with βότρυς, it describes the grapes rather than the cluster on which they grow" (Swete, Apoc., 187 f.).†
an ear of corn: Mat.12.1, Mar.2.23; Mar.4.28, Luk.6.1.†
Stachys: Rom.16.9 (v. Lft., Phi., 174; MM, xxiii).†
a roof: Mar.2.4; of entering a house, εἰσέρχεσθαι ὑπὸ τὴν σ., Mat.8.8, Luk.7.6 (cf. MM, xxiii).†

1. prop., to cover closely, to protect by covering, esp. to keep water in or out (Soph., Plat., al.).; 2. to cover, keep secret, conceal (Sir, l.c., Polyb., al.): 1Co.13.7, R, mg.; 3. By covering to ward of, bear up under, endure (for exx., v., Lft., Notes, 40; M, Th., 36): 1Co.9.12; 1Co.13.7, 1Th.3.1; 1Th.3.5.†
also -α, -ον,; barren: of a woman, Luk.1.7; Luk.1.36; Luk.23.29, Gal.4.27 (LXX).†

1. prop., to set, place, arrange, fit out; hence, mid., to set oneself for, prepare (Wis, xi Mac, ll. c.).; 2. to bring together, gather up (in Hom. of furling sails), hence to restrain,, check; mid., to restrain or withdraw oneself, hold aloof, avoid: 2Co.8.20; seq. ἀπό, 2Th.3.6
a wreath, garland: as used in sacrifices, Act.14.13.†
a groaning: Act.7.34 (LXX κραυγή), Rom.8.26.†

to groan ("the word denotes feeling which is internal and unexpressed," Mayor, Ja., 162): Mar.7.34, 2Co.5.2; 2Co.5.4, Heb.13.17, Jas.5.9 (EV, murmur); ἐν ἑαυτοῖς, Rom.8.23 (cf. ἀνα-, συ(ν)-στενάζω).†; SYN.: see κλαίω G2799.
narrow: fig (v MM, xxiii), Mat.7.13-14, Luk.13.24.†
1. to be straitened (cf. Isa.49.19); metaph., to be anxious (Hipp., al.).; 2. In late writers, trans., to straiten, compress (LXX, Diod., al.; Papyri ap. MM, xxiii): pass., trop., 2Co.4.8; 2Co.6.12.†

narrowness of space, want of room (Thuc., al.). Metaph. (Ken., Polyb., Deu.28.53, Wis.5.3, al.), difficulty, distress: θλίψις καὶ (ἢ) σ., Rom.2.9; Rom.8.35 (EV, anguish); pl. (cf. Bl., § 32, 6; WM, 220), 2Co.6.4; 2Co.12.10.†; SYN.: θλίψις G2347, q.v.
hard, firm, solid: τροψή, Heb.5.12; Heb.5.14; θεμέλιος, fig., 2Ti.2.19. Metaph.,; (a) in bad sense, hard, cruel (Hom., al.); (b) in good sense, steadfast, firm: τ. πίστει, 1Pe.5.9.†
(a) to make firm or solid; (b) to strengthen, make strong; c. acc pers., Act.3.16; τ. βάσεις,, pass., Act.3.7. Metaph. (cf. Je, l.c.): τ. πίστει,, pass., Act.16.5.†

a solid body; (a) a support, foundation (Arist., al.); metaph., strength (Psa.17.1-15; Psa.70.1-5, 1Mac, ll. c.); steadfastness, firmness: τ. πίστεως, Col.2.5; (b) the dome of heaven (believed to be a solid canopy), the firmament (LXX).†

1. that which surrounds or encompasses (as a wall, a crowd: Hom., al.).; 2. a crown, i.e. the wreath, garland or chaplet given as a prize for victory, as a festal ornament, or as a public honour for disting­uished service or personal worth (so to sovereigns, especially on the occasion of a παρουσία, q.v.; cf. Deiss., LAE, 372 ff.; on its use in LXX for the golden crown of royalty (prop., διάδημα, q.v., cf. Hort and Mayor on Jas.1.12): Mat.27.29, Mar.15.17, Joh.19.2; Joh.19.5, 1Co.9.25, Rev.4.4; Rev.4.10; Rev.6.2; Rev.9.7; Rev.12.1; Rev.14.14. Metaph.: Php.4.1, Rev.3.11; τ. δικαιοσύνης (cf. Deiss., LAE, 312), 2Ti.4.8; τ. δόξης, 1Pe.5.4; καυχήσεως, 1Th.2.19 (v. M, Th., in l); τ. ζωῆς (gen. appos.), Jas.1.12, Rev.2.10.†
c. acc pers.,; to crown: of a victor, 2Ti.2.5. Metaph., δόξῃ κ. τιμῇ, Heb.2.7; Heb.2.9 (LXX).†
the breast: Joh.13.25; Joh.21.10, Rev.15.6; as a sign of penitence, τύπτειν (εἰς) τὸ σ., Luk.18.13; Luk.23.48,†

late Pres., formed from pen., ἕστηκα (v. B1., § 17; WH, App., 169; Kennedy, Sources, 158; M, Pr., 238; MM, xxiii),; = ἵστημι, to stand: Mar.3.31; Mar.11.25, Joh.1.26, Rev.12.4 (ἕστηκεν T). Metaph., to stand firm, stand fast: absol., Gal.5.1 (but v. Field, Notes, 189 f.), 2Th.2.15; seq. ἐν, Joh.8.44 (ἕστηκεν, T, R, mg.), 1Co.16.13, Php.1.27; Php.4.1; c. dat., Rom.14.4.†
1. a setting firmly, supporting.; 2. fixedness, firmness, steadfastness: 2Pe.3.17.†

to fix, set fast, make fast: Luk.16.26; τ. πρόσωτον (Eze.6.2; Eze.13.17, al.; v. Dalman, Words, 30 f.), Luk.9.51. Metaph., to confirm, establish: c., acc, Luk.22.32, Act.18.23, Rom.1.11; Rom.16.25, 1Th.3.2; 1Th.3.13, 2Th.3.3, Jas.5.8, 1Pe.5.10, Rev.3.2; id. seq. ἐν, 2Th.2.17, 2Pe.1.12.†
a tattoed mark or brand: τὰ σ. τοῦ Ἰησοῦ, Gal.6.17 (v. Lft., in l; Deiss., BS, 349; LAE, 303; MM, xxiii).†
a prick, a point; metaph., σ. χρόνου, a moment: Luk.4.5.†
to shine, glisten: Mar.9.3.†
a portico: Joh.5.2; used of the covered colonnade in the Temple (EV, porch), Joh.10.23 Act.3.11; Act.5.12 †
** στιβάς, -άδος, ἡ,; a litter of leaves or rushes: pl., Mar.11.8 (Rec. στοιβ-).†

prop.,; one of a row (στοῖχος) or series, hence,; 1. the shadow-line of a dial (Aristoph.).; 2. an elementary sound or letter of the alphabet (Anth., Plut., Papyri).; 3. the elements or rudiments of knowledge (Arist., al.) Heb.5.12; πτωχὰ σ., Gal.4.9; σ. τοῦ κόσμου, Gal.4.3, Col.2.8; Col.2.20 (but v. infr.).; 4. The material elements of the universe (Plat.; LXX, ll. c.): 2Pe.3.10; 2Pe.3.12.; 5. The heavenly bodies (Ding. Laert.).; 6. The demons or tutelary spirits of nature (Enoch., Test., Sol., al.; for this sense in Ga, Col, ll. c., v. ICC on Col.2.8; Enc. Bibl., s.v. " Elements ").†

to be in rows (of waves, plants, etc., as well as of men), to walk in line (esp. of marching in file to battle; Xen., Cyr., vi, 3, 34, al.). Metaph., in late writers, to walk by rule: Act.21.24; c. dat., to walk by or in (as a rule of life), Rom.4.12 (cf. MM, xxiii), Gal.5.25; Gal.6.16, Php.3.16 (cf. συν-στοιχέω).†

1, an equipment, an armament (Æsch.).; 2. Equipment in clothes, apparel, esp. flowing raiment, a festal robe: (cf. Jh 3:6, Ezr.8.15, 1Ma.6.15): Mar.12.38; Mar.16.5, Luk.15.22; Luk.20.46, Rev.6.11; Rev.7.9; Rev.7.13-14; Rev.22.14.†

the mouth: of man, Mat.15.11, Joh.19.29, Act.11.8, al.; of animals, Mat.17.27, 2Ti.4.17 (fig.), Heb.11.33, Jas.3.3, al.; fig., of inanimate things (ποταμοῦ, Hom.), ἤνοιξεν ἡ γῆ τὸ σ., Rev.12.16; σ. μαχαίρας (Heb. H2719־H6310, Gen.34.26 al.), the edge of the sword, Luk.21.24, Heb.11.34; esp. of the mouth as the organ of speech: opp. to καρδία, Mat.12.34, Rom.10.8; Rom.10.10; in various phrases (some cl., some resembling Hebrew; cf. Bl., § 40, 9): ἀνοίγειν τ. σ. (see ἀνοίγω); σ. πρὸς σ. (H6310־H413 H6310 Num.12.8; = cl., κατὰ σ., Hdt., al.), face to face, 2Jn.1.12, 3Jn.1.14; διὰ τοῦ σ. (of the Holy Spirit), Luk.1.70, Act.1.16, al.; ἀπὸ (ἐκ) τοῦ σ. (cf. ἀπὸ σ. εἰπεῖν, Plat., al.), of speaking by word of mouth, Luk.22.71, Act.22.14; δόλος (ψεῦδος) ἐν τ. σ., 1Pe.2.22, Rev.14.5 (LXX); metaph., ἡ ῥομφαία τοῦ σ., Rev.2.16. By meton., for speech (Soph.): Mat.18.16 (LXX), Luk.19.22; Luk.21.15, 2Co.13.1.
prop.,; a mouth, an opening; (a) in early Gk. writers, the throat; (b) of the opening of the stomach (Arist.); (c) in later writers (Plut., al.), the stomach: 1Ti.5.23.†
an expedition, a campaign, warfare: metaph., 2Co.10.4 (-τιά, T), 1Ti.1.18.†
1. = στρατεία (Hdt., al.).; 2. an army, a host: pl., Mat.22.7, Rev.9.16; Rev.19.14; Rev.19.19; = soldiers, company of soldiers, Act.23.10; Act.23.27; pl., Luk.23.11.†

and depon., -ομαι, so always in NT; used of the general, to make war, do battle, and (chiefly) of the soldiers serving under him, to serve as a soldier: Luk.3.14, 1Co.9.7, 2Ti.2.4. Metaph. (cf. MM, ii, xxiii), of spiritual conflict, to war, make war: 2Co.10.3, 1Ti.1.18, Jas.4.1, 1Pe.2.11.†

1. a military commander, a general (Hdt., al.).; 2. A civic commander, a governor, magistrate (Hdt., Xen., al.): Act.16.20; Act.16.22; Act.16.35-36; Act.16.38.; 3. The commander of the Levitical guard of the Temple, ὁ σ. τ. ἱεροῦ (EV, captain of the Temple): Act.4.1; Act.5.24; Act.5.26; pl., Luk.22.4; Luk.22.52.†; SYN.: ἄρχων G758 (cf. EGT on Act.16.20; Ramsay, St. Paul, 217).

1. = στρατός, an army, a host: of angels (1Ki.22.19, al.), Luk.2.13; of the stars of heaven (Jer.8.2, 2Ch.33.3), Act.7.42.; 2. As sometimes in cl. (poët.), = στρατεία: 2Co.10.4, T (WH, RV, στρατεία).†
a soldier: Mat.8.9, Mar.15.16, Joh.19.2, Act.10.7, al.; metaph., σ. Χριστοῦ Ἰησ., 2Ti.2.3.†
to levy a troop, enlist soldiers: 2Ti.2.4 (Diod., Plut., al.).†
στρατοπεδάρχης, see στρατοπέδαρχος.
(a) a military camp; (b) an army: Luk.21.20.†
to twist, torture. Metaph. (cf. 2Ki, l.c.), to twist or pervert language: 2Pe.3.16.†

to turn: c. acc rei dat. pers., Mat.5.39; = ἀποσ-, to bring back, Mat.27.3 (cf. Isa.38.8); reflexively (WM, § 38, 1), to turn oneself, Act.7.42; c. acc seq. εἰς, = μετασ-, to change, Rev.11.6. Pass., reflexive, to turn oneself: seq. εἰς, Joh.20.14, Act.7.39; Act.13.46; ptcp., στραφείς, c. indic., Mat.7.6; Mat.9.22; Mat.16.23, Luk.7.9; Luk.9.55; Luk.14.25; Luk.22.61, Joh.1.38; Joh.20.16; id. seq. πρός, Luk.7.44; Luk.10.22 (WH, R, om.), Luk.7.23; Luk.23.28; metaph., to change: absol., Mat.18.3, Joh.12.40 (cf. ἀνα-, ἀπο-, δια-, ἐκ, ἐπι-, κατα-, μετα-, συ(ν)-, ὑπο-στρέφω).†
a word which first appears in the middle comedy (Rutherford, NPhr., 475 f.), to run riot, wax wanton: Rev.18.7-9 (cf. κατα-στρηνιάω).†; SYN.: σπαταλάω G4684 (q.v.), τρυφάω G5171.
insolent luxury, wantonness: Rev.18.3 (a late word, first found in a Comic poet, B.C. 300, v. Kennedy, Sources, 41, cf. στρηνιάω).†
dimin. of στρουθός,; a sparrow: Mat.10.29; Mat.10.31, Luk.12.6-7.†

to spread: ἱμάτια ἐν τ. ὁδῷ (εἰς τ. ὁδόν), Mat.21.8, Mar.11.8; of making a bed, στρῶσον (sc. τ. κλίνην) σεαυτῷ, Act.9.34; of furnishing a room, ἐστρωμένον, spread with carpets or carpeted couches (cf. Eze.23.41), Mar.14.15, Luk.22.12.†
hated, hateful: Tit.3.3.†
to have a sombre, gloomy appearance: of the human countenance (RV, his countenance fell), Mar.10.22; of the sky (so στυγνότης, Polyb., iv, 21, 1), Mat.16.3 ([WH], R, mg., om.).†
a pillar, regarded especially as a support: σ. πυρός, Rev.10.1; σ. ἐν τ. ναῷ, fig., Rev.3.12, Metaph., Gal.2.9; τ. ἀληθείας, 1Ti.3.15.†
Stoic: Act.17.18.†; Στοϊκός, see Στωικός.

pron. of 2nd pers.,; thou, you, gen., σοῦ, dat., σοί, acc, σέ, pl., ὑμεῖς, -ῶν, -ῖν, -ᾶς (enclitic in oblique cases sing., except after prep. (B1., § 48, 3), though πρὸς σέ occurs in Mat.25.39). Nom, for emphasis or contrast: Joh.1.30; Joh.1.42; Joh.4.10; Joh.5.38-39; Joh.5.44, Act.4.7, Eph.5.32; so also perhaps σὺ εἶπας, Mat.26.64, al. (M, Pr., 86); before voc., Mat.2.6, Luk.1.76, Joh.17.5, al.; sometimes without emphasis (M, Pr., 85 f.), as also in cl., but esp. as rendering of Heb. phrase, e.g. υἱός μου εἶ σύ (H1121־ H859, Psa.2.7), Act.13.33 The gen. (σοῦ, ὑμῶν) is sometimes placed bef. the noun: Luk.7.48; Luk.12.30, al.; so also the enclitic σου, Mat.9.6; on τί ἐμοὶ κ. σοί, see ἐγώ.
1. kinship.; 2. By meton., kinsfolk, kindred: Luk.1.61, Act.7.3; Act.7.14 †

σνγγενής, -ές; 1. congenital, natural, innate.; 2. akin to; as subst., a kinsman: Mar.6.4, Luk.1.58; Luk.2.44; Luk.14.12; Luk.21.16, Joh.18.26, Act.10.24; of tribal kinship, Rom.9.3; Rom.16.7; Rom.16.11; Rom.16.21.†; SYN.: ἴδιος G2398, οἰκεῖος G3609 (q.v.).; *† συγγενίς, -ίδος, ἡ,; late fem. form of σνγγενής, q.v.,; a kinswoman: Luk.1.36.†
1. confession.; 2. fellow feeling; hence, concession, allowance: 1Co.7.6 (v. ICC, in l).; 3. pardon.†; συγγνώμη, see συνγνώμη.
to sit together or with: c. dat., Act.26.30; seq. μετά, c. gen., Mar.14.54.†

1. to invest, besiege (Diod., 2Ki.6.24, 1Ma.11.61, al.).; 2. to sit around: Luk.22.55, L, txt.†; συν-καθίζω; 1. trans., to make to sit together: c. acc pers., seq. ἐν, Eph.2.6.; 2. Intrans. = mid., to sit together: Luk.22.55.†
to endure adversity with: c. dat. pers., Heb.11.25. Not elsewhere.†

to call together: c. acc, Mar.15.16, Luk.15.6; Luk.15.9 (v.l. -εῖται, v. B1., § 55, 1), Act.5.21. Mid., to call together to oneself: Luk.9.1 (and v.l. in Luk.15.6; Luk.15.9 v. supr.) Luk.23.13, Act.10.24; Act.28.17.†
to veil or cover completely: c. acc, pass., Luk.12.2.†
to bend completely, bend together: τ. νῶτον, fig., Rom.11.10 (LXX).†
to go down with: Act.25.5. In late writers also metaph. (Wis, l.c.), to condescend, on WH. v. Rutherford, NPhr., 485 f.†
concord, agreement: 2Co.6.16 (Polyb., Plut., al.).†
to deposit together. Mid., to deposit one's vote with, hence, to agree with, assent to: c. dat., Luk.23.51.†
1. to condemn with or together (Plut., Themist., 21).; 2. to vote one a place among: pass., Act.1.26. Not elsewhere .†

to mix or blend together, compound: c. acc, 1Co.12.24; ptcp. pf. pass., Heb.4.2, T, WH, mg., R, mg.; id., of persons, c. dat. instr., to be united with, agree with, ib., WH, txt., R, txt. (v. Westc., in l).†
to move together. Metaph., to excite, stir up: τ. λαόν, Act.6.12 (Arist., Polyb., al.).†
to shut together, enclose, shut in on all sides: of a catch of fish, Luk.5.6; metaph. (Psa.31.9, al.), Rom.11.32, Gal.3.22-23. †
a co-inheritor, fellow-heir: Rom.8.17, Eph.3.6; c. gen. rei, Heb.11.9, 1Pe.3.7 (for exx., v. Deiss., LAE, 88 f.).†
to have fellowship with or in (in cl., c. gen. rei, dat. pers.): c. dat. rei, Eph.5.11, Rev.18.4; id. c. gen. pers., Php.4.14.†
partaking jointly of: c. gen. rei, Rom.11.17, 1Co.9.23; id. c. gen. pers., Php.1.7; seq. ἐν, Rev.1.9.†
1. to bring together, collect (Hdt., Xen., al.).; 2. to take up a body for burial (Soph., Aj., 1048): Act.8.2 (v. Field, Notes, 116).†

1. to compound, combine: 1Co.2.13, R, mg.1 (Lft., Notes, 180 f.).; 2. In Arist. and later writers (Wis.7.29, a1.) = παραβάλλω, to compare: 1Co, l.c., R, txt. (Field, Notes, 168), 2Co.10.12.; 3. In LXX, of dreams, to interpret (Gen.40.8, 1Co, l.c., R, mg. 2 (but v. reff. supr.).†
1. to bend forwards (Arist., al.).; 2. to be bowed down: Luk.13.11.†
1. to rejoice with: c. dat pers., Luk.1.58; Luk.15.6; Luk.15.9, Php.2.17-18, EV; c. dat. rei, 1Co.12.26; 1Co.13.6.; 2. to congratulate (Æschin., Polyb., al.): Phi, l.c. (Lft., in I.; cf. MM, xxiv).†

to pour together, commingle, confuse; metaph., confound, throw into confusion, stir up trouble: Act.21.27 (cf. συν-χύννω).†; † συν-χύννω; Hellenistic form of -χέω (q.v.): Act.2.6; Act.9.22; Act.19.32; Act.21.31.†; χέω, see χύνω.
to use together with. Metaph., c. dat. pers., to associate with: Joh.4.9 (Polyb., a1.).†
confusion: of a popular uproar, Act.19.29.†
to live with: opp. to συναποθανεῖν, 2Co.7.3; of life in union with Christ, here and hereafter, Rom.6.8, 2Ti.2.11.†
to yoke to­gether: metaph., of union in wedlock, Mat.19.6, Mar.10.9.†

1. to search or examine together (Plat.).; 2. In NT (and Papyri, v. MM, xxiii; also in MGr., v. Kennedy, Sources, 155), to discuss, dispute: Mar.1.27; Mar.12.28, Luk.24.15; seq. quæst. indir., Mar.9.10; c. dat. pers., Mar.8.11 Act.6.9; seq. πρός, c. acc pers., Mar.9.14; Mar.9.16, Act.9.29; id. seq. quæst. indir., Luk.22.23.†
disputation: Act.28.29 (WH, R, txt., om.).†
a disputer, disputant: 1Co.1.20.†
or as WH, mg., Σύνζυγος, -ον; a yoke fellow. Prob., as proper name, Σ. γνήσιε, genuinely Synzygus, S. properly so-called, Php.4.3 (v. ICC, Lft., in l; MM, xxiii).†
to make alive or quicken together with; metaph., of the spiritual life: τ. Χριστῷ, Eph.2.5; σὺν τ. Χ., Col.2.13.†
the mulberry tree; the sycamine: Luk.17.6. (In LXX, σ. appears to represent the συκόμορος (see συκομορέα), but St. Luke distinguishes between the two; v. ICC, in l; DB, iv, 634.) †

to act the συκοφάντης (on conjectures as to the origin of the term, v. LS, s.v.), to accuse falsely (Aristoph., Xen., al.): Luk.3.14 (R, mg.) Luk.19.8 (RV, exact wrongfully; but cf. Hatch, Essays, 89 ff., v. also Field, Notes, 56 f.; MM, xxiv).†
to carry off as spoil, lead captive (θυγατέρα, Heliod., Aeth., 10, 35): metaph., Col.2.8.†
c. acc pers., to strip, plunder, spoil: 2Co.11.8.†
to talk with or together: c. dat. pers., Mar.9.4, Luk.9.30; Luk.22.4; seq. μετά, c. gen., Mat.17.3, Act.25.12; πρός, c. acc, Luk.4.36.†

1. c. acc, to bring together, collect.; 2. to seize, take: c. acc pers., as a prisoner, Mat.26.55, Mar.14.48, Luk.22.54, Joh.18.12, Act.1.16; Act.12.3; pass., Act.23.27; mid., in sense of act., Act.26.21; σ. ἄγραν ἰχθύων, Luk.5.9.; 3. C. dat. pers., to take part with, assist, succour; mid., in same sense: Luk.5.7, Php.4.3.; 4. Of a woman, to conceive: absol., Luk.1.24; seq. ἐν γαστρί, Luk.1.31; c. acc, Luk.1.36; ib. seq. ἐν τ. κοιλίᾳ, Luk.2.21; metaph., of lust producing sin, Jas.1.15.†
to bring together, collect, gather up: c. acc rei, Mat.13.28-30; pass., Mat.13.40; c. acc, seq. ἀπό, Mat.7.16; id. seq. ἐκ, Mat.13.41, Luk.6.44; seq. εἰς, Mat.13.48.†
1. to compute.; 2. to reason: Luk.20.5.†
to make to grieve with (Arist.). Pass., to be moved to grief by sympathy: seq. ἐπί, c. dat., Mar.3.5.†

1. to stand with the feet together.; 2. to come together, come to terms.; 3. Of events, to come to pass, happen: c. dat. pers., Mar.10.32, Act.3.10; Act.20.19, 1Co.10.11, 1Pe.4.12, 2Pe.2.22; absol., τὰ σνμβεβηκότα, Luk.24.14 (cf. 1Ma.4.26); c. acc et nf., Act.21.35.†

to throw together, hence,; (a) of speech (seq. λόγους, Eur., al.), to discuss, confer (sc. λόγους): c. dat. pers., Luk.11.53, WH, mg., Act.17.18; seq. πρὸς ἀλλήλους, Act.4.15; (b) to reflect, consider, ponder: ἐν τ. καρδίᾳ, Luk.2.19; (c) to meet with, fall in with: Act.20.14; in hostile sense, εἰς πόλεμον, c. dat. (εἰς μάχην, Polyb.), Luk.14.31; (d) mid., to contribute (Polyb., al.; cf. MM, xxiv): Act.18.27.†

1. to advise, counsel: c. dat. pers., Joh.18.14; id. seq. inf., Rev.3.18.; 2. Mid., to take counsel, consult: seq. ἵνα, Mat.26.4 ("reciprocal middle," v. M, Pr., 157); c. inf., Act.9.23.†; **† συν-βασιλεύω; to reign together or with: metaph., of sharing the glories of the Kingdom of God, 1Co.4.8, 2Ti.2.12.†

1. to join or knit together, unite: Eph.4.16, Col.2.2 (but v. infr.), Col.2.19.; 2. to compare, consider, conclude (Plat.): Act.16.10.; 3. to deduce, prove, demonstrate (Arist.): Act.9.22.; 4. As in LXX ("translation Greek," = ἐμβιβάζω, metaph.), to teach, instruct: 1Co.2.16 Act.19.33, R, mg. (also in Vg., Col.2.2, instructi, but v. supr.).†
From G4862 and G1011

a word of the Græco-Roman period (of. Lat. consilium, and v. Deiss., BS, 238) = cl. συμβουλία (Arist., Xen.),; 1. counsel: σ. λαμβάνειν, Mat.12.14; Mat.22.15; Mat.27.7; Mat.28.12; διδόναι, Mar.3.6 (ποιεῖν, Rec.); ποιεῖν, Mar.15.1 (ἑτοιμάζειν, WH, mg.).; 2. By meton., a council (4Mac, l.c. א; συνέδριον, AR): Act.25.12 (v. MM, xxiv).†
a counsellor, adviser: Rom.11.34 (LXX).†

indecl.,; Simeon (so always AV; RV in Luk.2.25; Luk.2.34 only), Symeon, a Heb. name for which the Gk. Σίμων, q.v., was also used; 1. the son of Jacob (Gen.29.33): Rev.7.7.; 2. An ancestor of our Lord: Luk.3.30.; 3. An aged worshipper in the Temple: Luk.2.25; Luk.2.34.; 4. One surnamed Niger: Act.13.1.; 5. The apostle Peter: Act.15.14, 2Pe.1.1 (R, txt., WH, txt., Σίμων).†
a fellow-disciple: Joh.11.16 (on the use of συν- in such compounds as this, v. Rutherford, NPhr., 255 f.).†
to bear witness with: Rom.2.15; c. dat., Rom.8.16; seq. ὅτι, Rom.9.1.†
to distri­bute in shares. Mid., to have a share in: 1Co.9.13 (Diod., al.).†
partaking together with; as subst., ὁ σ., a joint partaker (c. dat. pers. et gen. rei, FlJ, BJ, i, 24, 6): c. gen. rei, Eph.3.6; c. gen. pers., Eph.5.7 (Arist.).†
a fellow-imitator: c. gen. obj., Php.3.17 (v. ICC, in l). Not elsewhere.†
1. absol., similar (Luc.).; 2. con­formed to: c. dat., Php.3.21; c. gen., Rom.8.29 (v. B1., § 36, 11; 37, 6).†
Rec. for -ίζω (q.v.), Php.3.10.†; *† συμ-μορφίζω (T, συν-),; to conform to: pass. ptcp., Php.3.10 (v. Lft., Phi., 128).†; συν-μορφίζω, see συμμορφίζω.
to have a fellow feeling for or with, sympathize with or in: c. dat. rei, Heb.4.15; dat. pers., Heb.10.34 (Arist., Plut., al.).†
1. affected by like feelings, sympathetic: 1Pe.3.8.; 2. exciting sympathy (Jb, l.c.; Dion. H.).†
1. to come up or be present together: seq. ἐπί, Luk.23.48.; 2. to come up to assist (Thuc., al.; 2Ti.4.16, Rec.).†
to call upon or exhort together (Plat.). Pass., to be strengthened or comforted with and among: Rom.1.12.†
to take along with: as a companion, c. acc, Act.12.25; Act.15.37-38 (on the tenses, v. M, Pr., 130), Gal.2.1.†
Rec, for παρα-μένω G3887 (q.v.), Php.1.25.†
to be present together or with: c. dat. pers., Act.25.24.†
1. to suffer together or with: Rom.8.17, 1Co_12:28.; 2. to sympathize with (Plat., Arist.).†
to send together with: c. acc et dat., 2Co.8.22; id. seq. μετά, c. gen., 2Co.8.18.†
1. to enclose (Eze.5.3 (H6696) *).; 2. to embrace: c. acc pers., Act.20.10.†

1. a drinking party.; 2. By meton., of the party itself, the guests (Plut); pl., σ. σ. (colloq.; v. M, Pr., 97), in parties or companies: Mar.6.39.†; συν-πίνω; to drink with c. dat. pers., Act.10.41.†
